urn:contentItem:5WC4-8C01-JB20-G0HB-00000-00President Donald Trump Agrees with Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez about his Reelection Chances; Pfizer to Buy Array Biopharma in $11.4 Billion Deal; Bitcoin Tops $9,000; Gary Woodland Wins U.S. Open; Babe Ruth Jersey Sells Record $5.64 Million at Auction2019-06-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:18ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMitch Roschelle, Alex JosephsonNEWSFinancial061702cb.231President Donald Trump Agrees with Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez about his Reelection Chances; Pfizer to Buy Array Biopharma in $11.4 Billion Deal; Bitcoin Tops $9,000; Gary Woodland Wins U.S. Open; Babe Ruth Jersey Sells Record $5.64 Million at AuctionMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Jared Max, Jessica Tarlov, Lauren Simonetti, Andrew Napolitano

ANNOUNCER: Live from France at the 2019 Cannes Lions, here's Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hi (PH).

MARIA BARTIROMO, CNN HOST, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: Good Monday morning live from beautiful Cannes, France. It is Monday, June 17th. We are coming to you live from the Cannes Lions conference and it is 7 A.M. on the East Coast. Your top stories right now.

Markets are pointing to a slightly higher opening this morning for the broader averages. Take a look. Dow Industrial's holding onto a point, S&P's also up a point and the Nasdaq up 8.5. I should point out that this is off of the best levels of the morning in terms of futures. We will keep watching that. It is a big week where the Federal Reserve will have a two- day meeting. Friday, markets ended the day down slightly, but they were up for the week. As you see, the Dow was down 17 on Friday, the S&P was down 4 and the Nasdaq lower by 40 points.

In Europe this morning, the major indices look like this. European markets today are mixed. FT 100's down 9.5, CAC quarante in Paris is up 10 and the DAX index in Germany down one point. In Asia overnightm markets were mostly higher with the exception of Korea, but here too very much fractional moves across the board. In Hong Kong, government offices are closed today following the massive protests in the streets yesterday. We've got more on that coming up.

Meanwhile, big technology in focus. The CEO of Apple, Tim Cook, says that tech giants need to take responsibility for the chaos that they create. Plus, Facebook takes action against Huawei this morning. Coming up, Connell McShane is live from China. He is on the ground in China with an inside look at Huawei and the troubles that the company is facing today. That's coming up, 8:30 A.M. this morning, Eastern time, right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

The 2020 race is on, Congressman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez says that Democrats have a real risk of losing to Donald Trump. The president's response, plus new Fox News polls right here.

And Bitcoin is soaring once again this morning. Why the cryptocurrency is climbing above $9,000, as you see, all those stories coming up right here and joining me to break it all down in New York, Fox Business Network's Cheryl Casone, along with PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle. Good morning, guys.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Good morning.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: Good morning.

CASONE: Is it as beautiful there as it looks here to us?

BARTIROMO: Yes, it definitely is. Yes.

ROSCHELLE: Well, it's partly cloudy here. Just if you wanted a New York city weather report, it's partly cloudy.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but the same issues are there and here. We're talking about the same things. Here we have the Federal Reserve meeting this week and I'd like to know, Cheryl, why are we talking about a cut in interest rates when the economy seems to be growing so strongly?

CASONE: Exactly. Well, look, you know how market participants are. They want nothing but free, easy money and if we could go back to zero, I think Wall Street would be thrilled. But you're right. The economy is doing great. Jobs, unemployment at a -- at a 30-year low. So there's no really strong reason for the rate cut, but I got to say, President Trump would like to see one. So we'll see if that pressure on Jay Powell that he's been putting onto the Fed chair will make ant difference and maybe they'll talk about it at the meeting this week. We'll see.

BARTIROMO: And of course, Mitch, when you have rock bottom rates, it's giving you very few alternatives for your money so that's why we usually see the stock market trade up when you've got such low rates because you're not getting any return in fixed income.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. And one of the reasons why the 10-year treasury and the entire treasury curve has come down is because the rates around the world are so low and we've talked about this a bunch. The fact of the matter is you've got Germany and Japan with negative interest rates on their 10-year treasury. So not only do investors around the world like U.S. treasuries, but they also like U.S. stocks when the treasuries fall.

So that's why there's a flood of money coming here and I agree our economy's fundamentally strong. I can't wait to hear what the Fed has to say about rates, but there's not a lot of pricing in of rate cut (PH) 24 percent for the June meeting, but 85 percent for the July meeting. So the market is banking on a rate cut this year, this summer.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, we'll hear Tuesday and Wednesday, two-day meeting from the Fed. We also have today, there are public hearings for the president's tariffs against China.

CASONE: Right.

BARTIROMO: So we'll talk about that. We got a big three hours here. Former senior advisor to President George W. Bush Karl Rove is joining us this morning, along with the chairman of Laffer Associates, Art Laffer, who was (PH) the former Reagan economic adviser.

We'll talk with Art about economic trends right now and Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano joins us, along with U.S. Soccer hall-of-famer and Fox Sports analyst Alexi Lalas is with us this morning and two-time Olympic gold medalist, lead match analyst for the FIFA Women's World Cup, Aly Wagner joining us as well. Don't miss a moment of it. We got a big couple of hours right here.

[07:05:00] We want to kick this hour off with this, the big tech threat, the industry battling for its future against potential new regulations as Congress ramps up regulations on Silicon Valley's largest companies or at least talks about doing so. Facebook fighting to rebuild trust as well. The networking giant now boosting spending on advertising amid a wave of antitrust and privacy probes.

The CEO of Apple, Tim Cook, targeting some of the biggest names in tech over the weekend. In his Stanford commencement speech, Tim Cook says that companies must take responsibility for the chaos that they create. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: This industry is becoming better known for a less noble innovation, the belief that you can claim credit without accepting responsibility. With every data breach, every privacy violation, every blind eye turned to hate speech, fake news poisoning our national conversation, the false miracles in exchange for a single drop of your blood, too many seem to think that good intentions excuse away harmful outcomes. But if you built a chaos factory, you can't dodge responsibility for the chaos. Taking responsibility means having the courage to think things through.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is the head of global brand strategy for Twitter, Alex Josephson and Alex, it is great to have you on the program.

ALEX JOSEPHSON, HEAD OF GLOBAL BRAND STRATEGY, TWITTER: Thanks for having me, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining. So let's take a step back. Your reaction to everything going on within technology today, whether it's the breach of privacy or the calls from Congress that Twitter and others censor conservative speech. What's your reaction?

JOSEPHSON: Sure. So technology brings the world closer together, it enhances culture, it creates jobs, right?

BARTIROMO: It certainly can.

JOSEPHSON: But any platform that plays a part in that has a responsibility to the users, to the customers who use their service and we take data protection and data privacy at Twitter, for example, we take it very, very seriously. We have really strict regulations in place for any third party that licenses our data. That's both with that technology that we have, teams that we have, reviewing the data licensing in detail manually.

And the reality is our platform is public. So whenever a user signs up to use the service, everything they're doing on the service, engaging with a tweet, sending a tweet, that's all public information and that's the only information that we license to any sort of third party.

BARTIROMO: How do you make those decisions, Alex? Because, you know, people are saying, look, you know, why is it that one person gets thrown off the Twitter platform because they didn't -- the speech fit those descriptions ...

JOSEPHSON: Sure.

BARTIROMO: ... and then somebody else isn't? And they'll say, well, maybe because that person's conservative and that person's liberal.

JOSEPHSON: Sure. So just to be really clear, ideology, subjectivity plays zero role in any decisions we make when we're taking action either on a user or on a tweet or any sort of behavior on the platform.

BARTIROMO: And are you watching this?

JOSEPHSON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: I mean, as (PH) one of the leaders of the company ...

JOSEPHSON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Do you watch, in fact, what you want to do is actually being executed that way?

JOSEPHSON: Absolutely. So historically, we put too much responsibility, too much onus on the users to report those actions and behaviors to us, but over the course of the last 12 to 18 months, we've implemented machine learning technology that knows what to look for both from an imagery standpoint and a tech standpoint and it proactively detects behaviors that are in violations of our terms and service and of our policies. We've proactively taken action on 40 percent more of those instances this year versus a year ago.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I've been watching this a lot because I've been hearing a lot on AI.

JOSEPHSON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And even with artificial intelligence, there's an implicit bias, isn't there?

JOSEPHSON: Well, I mean we have a team of humans also watching the algorithms and refining them ...

BARTIROMO: OK.

JOSEPHSON: ... and course correcting them.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JOSEPHSON: So we're proud of the progress we've made over the course of the last year. With that said, health on the platform is our number one priority and we're continuing to invest in that and we're continuing to refine that. And we know we have a lot of work to do ahead of us, but we are proud of the progress we've made.

BARTIROMO: It's funny. You're in charge of brand strategy and yet we are all using Twitter. It's like it's -- the brand is out there.

JOSEPHSON: Sure.

BARTIROMO: I mean, you've got the president of the United States, the president of India, I mean, using Twitter. This is ...

JOSEPHSON: Sure. Well, all the world leaders are on Twitter. My team specifically at Twitter, we work with the biggest CMOs and the biggest brands and their agency partners around the world, helping them get their brand strategy on Twitter right and a lot of that comes down to understanding our audience, listening to our audience and what really comes into play is when a brand is launching something new or trying to connect with a moment in culture and that's where we really get involved.

BARTIROMO: I think you make such a good point in terms of you working with the other CMOs because what I keep finding from all these chief marketing officers is they're trying to reach young people, they're trying to reach - - this is right in your sweet spot. You've got them.

JOSEPHSON: It is. We just published research with Interpublic Group, which is one of the major holding companies in the -- in the ad agency space.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JOSEPHSON: It says that cultural relevance drives 25 percent of all product purchase decisions and ...

BARTIROMO: Cultural relevance.

JOSEPHSON: Cultural relevance. So brands who lean into what's happening in the world and have a point of view, those are the brands that are winning the hearts and minds, particularly as you age down amongst consumers, when it comes to Millennials, when it comes to Gen Z.

[07:10:01] Gen Z users who use Twitter, say they open the app -- daily active users, they open the app multiple times a day, more than 70 percent of Gen Z does that.

BARTIROMO: That's amazing. And what really resonates with them is that there's purpose, that there's -- they want like when they want to go work somewhere, they don't necessarily just want to go make a lot of money. They want a company that actually believes in something, has convictions.

JOSEPHSON: That's right. That's right. Yes. I mean, 70 percent of Gen Zs are buying products from brands because they agree with them on certain social issues. A third of them have already boycotted brands because they disagree with them and brands are leaning into that, particularly when it comes to launching new purpose messaging ...

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JOSEPHSON: ... or connecting their company's purpose to something that's happening in culture that's relevant to them. I think a campaign that we all expect to win big in Cannes this year is Nike's Just Do It campaign which all launched with a tweet from Colin Kaepernick's handle. We expect that to make a lot of noise this week in Cannes.

BARTIROMO: I wonder if that's going to be the winner of the award.

JOSEPHSON: It very -- it very well might.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JOSEPHSON: It started with a tweet and it ended up driving a $6 billion increase in Nike's market cap in two weeks' time.

BARTIROMO: How do you like -- you've got to feel great about that. It started with a tweet. You got to explain this new mystery that we're hearing about today from Elon Musk. You know what I'm talking about, right? The Tesla chief says that he has deleted his Twitter account. As it turns out, his Twitter account still exists, but he changed his user name and the new user name is Daddy DotCom.

JOSEPHSON: Well, you know, I can't speak on behalf of Elon Musk. I know his tweets send ripple effects through the platform. I think the infamous tweet about potentially taking Tesla private, that actually drove the stock up by 11 percent in 24 hours. So we talk a lot about starting with Twitter's audience to shape culture and build your brand and I think he's an example of that. I can't describe ...

BARTIROMO: He really is.

JOSEPHSON: I can't describe or explain his latest behaviors though (PH) ...

BARTIROMO: Daddy DotCom. OK. You just got off stage, right?

JOSEPHSON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You were -- you were just on stage. Tell me about that because you're also marking the launch of a new study that's looking at 2,000 Cannes Lions entries from 2014 to 2018 identifying critical characteristics ...

JOSEPHSON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: ... that define brand campaigns.

JOSEPHSON: Yes. So Cannes Lions is the -- it's the epicenter of creativity in advertising. It always has been. Half of Grand Prix and gold winners last year integrated Twitter into their -- into their campaigns and so we looked at the Twitter-led campaigns from the last half decade, as you mentioned, and we're really looking at the ones that started on Twitter and then transcended Twitter and either impacted the brand, the business and shaped culture in some unique way, shape or form.

BARTIROMO: And so do you see more CMOs spending money on that?

JOSEPHSON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Are they investing knowing that these are -- these issues are changing and they ...

JOSEPHSON: Absolutely. It's no longer an option to lean into Twitter and start with our audience. It's a necessity. You know, and we're seeing more brands activate on the platform and we're seeing brands that have been active on the platform invest in increasingly amounts year-on-year. We reported our Q1 earnings. Advertising revenue is up 18 percent year-on-year and that's a sign of the times and the sign of marketers knowing where they really have to start when it comes to their biggest audience of the year (PH) ...

BARTIROMO: So how do you deepen your relationships? How do you reach more people and get the user base increasing at Twitter ...

JOSEPHSON: Sure.

BARTIROMO: ... and how do you deepen that direct to consumer relationship?

JOSEPHSON: Yes. Absolutely. So we've seen eight consecutive quarters of daily active user growth on Twitter in the range of 9 percent to 14 percent. Q1 was no exception. We reported 11 percent in daily active user growth. All of that's a result of Twitter being what's happening in the world and the product refinements we've made over time to make the app more engaging, to make it more relevant for you. We see direct causation between the product changes we're making and the daily active user growth that we're seeing.

And of course that's all related to the growth in advertising spend that we're seeing on the platform. More users means more inventory. That means healthier ad engagements. Engagements are up -- ad performance is up on Twitter 23 percent year-on-year, cost is down 4 percent and all of that leads to the fact that the business is up 18 percent year-on-year.

BARTIROMO: So that's how you monetize this business. You monetize the platform in that -- it's just advertising. Very simple.

JOSEPHSON: That's right. It all comes down to our audience. So if you want to reach people who are interested in the NBA finals, or you want to reach K-pop fans -- there were 5 billion tweets about K-pop last year alone -- "Game of Thrones" fans, basically any conversation, any audience segment and particularly the ones that are becoming harder and harder to reach because the world is increasingly mobile, consumer fragmentation is at an all time high, that's our sweet spot for marketers.

BARTIROMO: All right. Well, I will go tweet about it.

JOSEPHSON: Please. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Thank you. Alex, it's good to see you. Thanks so much.

JOSEPHSON: It's great -- it's great to be here. Thanks for having us.

BARTIROMO: Alex Josephson. We'll be right back.

[07:15:00]

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, there is a new fear for border patrol agents. Lauren Simonetti in New York with headlines. Lauren?

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS, REPORTER: Maria, agents are concerned about exposure to illnesses. Union officials say migrants are showing up with the flu, chicken pox, measles. The breakouts being blamed in part on over- crowding in detention facilities and issues with quarantining. And the migrants influx isn't just coming from Latin America. Officials say people fleeing Africa for the U.S. on pace to triple this year.

Marijuana is not safe for teenage brains. That's the warning from two prominent health professionals, Kenneth Davis, the president of the Mount Sinai Health System, and Mary Kreek, a senior attending physician at Rockefeller University. They penned an op-ed in "The New York Times" saying marijuana can impair executive function, processing speed, memory, attention span and concentration. New York state and New Jersey are currently considering legalizing marijuana for those over the age of 21.

And this, inmates in California are allowed to possess marijuana, but they're not allowed to smoke it. A court rules that a law that legalized recreational possession of marijuana in 2016 did not make an exception for people who are incarcerated. That made laws criminalizing possession in prison obsolete. However, the court did point out, Maria, that smoking or ingesting marijuana is still a felony. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: Well, all right. Thank you so much, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Sure.

BARTIROMO: We'll take a short break. When we come back, Boeing's startling admission. The CEO is now acknowledging that the company made mistakes that led to those two fatal crashes. Details straight ahead.

And then Bitcoin back on the upside, the cryptocurrency hitting a one-year high this morning as Facebook says it's ready to unveil its own digital money. All that right after this.

[07:20:00]

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Boeing's startling admission. CEO Dennis Muilenburg acknowledged that the company did make mistakes in communication, saying that it should have been more transparent with regulators and with the public when it found a safety light malfunction. This as "The Wall Street Journal" reports that FAA flight trials for the 737 Max safety enhancement could begin this week. The 737 Max has been grounded now for months.

Joining us right now is Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano in New York. And Judge, it's always a pleasure to see you. What does this mean, that the CEO now makes this admission, acknowledges they made mistakes that led to the crashes -- people have died. The lawsuits obviously have probably begun already.

ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS, SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Well, I'm sure the lawsuits have begun. I'm also sure that Dennis Mulholland (PH) ran this statement past his legal department and his PR people before he made it and they came to the conclusion that the evidence is overwhelming. It's apparent what we did. It would be better -- because these cases are going to be resolved by juries. It would be better if we just admitted the obvious and dealt with it.

Now, I honestly don't know if they're self-insured. They probably have a self-insured retention and then insurance beyond that. They are not protected by the Warsaw or Montreal conventions because they're not a carrier. They're a manufacturer. So they are exposed to potential enormous, enormous liability.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes. I wonder where this goes. It's incredible because Boeing was doing so well and now you see countries pushing back and stopping orders, changing their order flow.

NAPOLITANO: Well, look, this was catastrophic and there may even be some chicanery involved.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: There may even be some inappropriate interaction -- may be. I don't know this to be so -- interaction with their regulator, with the FAA. You know, you get to a point where the entity being regulated knows more about the technical aspect of what's to be regulated than the government does and you find that the regulation is not what the law requires.

[07:25:00] I'm not very big on regulations, but you're talking about human safety and human life here and if any corners were cut ...

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: ... that's fodder for the Department of Justice to look into.

BARTIROMO: Speaking of Washington and government, there is a continuing push for impeachment on the Democrats' side. a group of Democrats rallying to impeach President Trump but House Speaker Nancy Pelosi says she's reluctant, instead encouraging action on issues like healthcare. Listen to what Tennessee Senator Marsha Blackburn said yesterday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES," Judge.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARSHA BLACKBURN, UNITED STATES SENATOR: The Democrats are getting mighty antsy about what might be found in that report and about what Attorney General Barr could possibly be looking at because they are the ones who did some outsourcing and working with the Russians and foreign nationals and trying to get information, the dossier paying for that through the Clinton campaign. Everybody is against foreign interference into U.S. policy or elections or influence or any such. It was wrong in 2016. It will be wrong in 2020 and forever more. The Russians have been trying to interfere in U.S. policy for decades.

So out of all this, I do congratulate my Democrat colleagues for finally admitting that Russia is not our friend. They're a foe. Of course, that is something that former president Obama obviously did not think was a problem because of the comments that he had back when Mitt Romney was his opponent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Judge, what about that? Do you think that this group of Democrats are going to win and move forward with impeaching, an impeachment trial?

NAPOLITANO: You know, the lead story in this morning's ...

BARTIROMO: Or hearing, rather.

NAPOLITANO: Right. The lead story in this morning's "Washington Post" is that Mrs. Pelosi is still in charge and she's still resisting impeachment. She's either resisting impeachment because she believes it will explode on the Democrats if it's not successful, and it's hard to believe that it would be, or she truly believes there are better things for the government to do.

I happen to agree with her on this, that impeachment is the wrong thing to do at the present time and the government has a lot of better things to do and the public has a lot more needs to fulfill, but the drum beat continues. Most of the people in favor of impeachment comprise a majority of the House Judiciary Committee. I don't know how much longer she can -- she can keep it down.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You know, I think if they don't do things for the American people, voters are going to have backlash come 2020. People want to feel like their representatives are actually working for them.

NAPOLITANO: I think Mrs. Pelosi understands that ...

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: ... but I think there are also members on the hard left side of the Democratic party who believe that their constituents want them to make Donald Trump's life miserable. To me, that's an inappropriate ...

BARTIROMO: Right.

NAPOLITANO: ... function for the government, making the president's life miserable, but they think this will assure their re-election.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: Mrs. Pelosi thinks it will assure their defeat and right now, she's still in charge.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And I think so. They've been resisting from day one. Judge, always a pleasure. Thank you.

NAPOLITANO: Enjoy France, my friend.

BARTIROMO: Judge Napolitano joining us there. I will. Thank you.

Coming up, 2020 is in focus. Freshman Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio- Cortez makes some predictions. What new Fox News polls are saying as well.

Then, Mariah Carey mix-up. Check this out. A cake order gone wrong, big- time. The link to the pop star coming up. Stay with us.

ANNOUNCER: Here again is Maria Bartiromo, with a special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA, live from France at the 2019 Cannes Lions.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, happy Monday everybody. It is Monday, June 17th. We're coming to you live from Cannes and here are your top stories right now, 7:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets are trying to hold onto gains but it is fractional, heading into the open this morning. Of course we have a Federal Reserve meeting later on in the week, Tuesday and Wednesday, people are anticipating that. Dow Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading, up 21 points on the Dow, S&P is up 2-1/2 and the NASDAQ higher by 14-1/4 right now.

This on top of a down day on Friday, although markets were up for the week on Friday. DowIndustrials were down 17 points at 4:00 on Wall Street. On Friday, the S&P was down 4-1/2 points and the NASDAQ was lower by 40 points.

European Indices this morning are mixed. Take a look at Europe right now where we see the FT-100 down seven points but the CAC Quarante in Paris up 11 and the DAX Index in Germany up by 1-1/2 points, fractional move there.

In Asia overnight, not much different. Mostly higher as you can see, although they were very fractional moves. The KOSPI Index was lower, down a quarter of a percent.

In Hong Kong, government offices are closed today following those massive protests in the streets yesterday.

Facebook taking action this morning against Huawei. The social media giant pulling ads from the company.

Coming up, Connell McShane is live on the ground in China this morning. He's giving us an inside look at Huawei and the trouble that the company is facing. That's at 08:30 a.m. Eastern this morning right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

Bitcoin is back up again, how's Facebook has the cryptocurrency climbing and above $9,000 this morning.

And U.S. Open crowns a champion, the highlights from Gary Woodland's exciting win, coming up right here.

Plus this, check out this -- wait, let's watch it -- watch it, there you go. Cake mistake, somebody wanted a Mariah Carey birthday cake but what they got was something very different. We will show you.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning. But first, we want to turn to the road to 2020, President Trump doubling down on a warning to Democrats. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D-NY): I think that we have a very real risk of losing the presidency to Donald Trump if we do not have a presidential candidate that is fighting for true transformational change in the lives of working people in the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez on the Sunday shows this weekend and President Trump used her words against her. Tweeting in part, I agree, and that is the only reason they play the impeach card which cannot be legally used, writes the president on the heels of Ocasio-Cortez comments.

The New York Democrat fires back then, she says this. Opening an impeachment inquiry is exactly what we must do when the president obstructs justice, advises witnesses to ignore legal subpoenas and more, writes AOC.

Joining me right now is Democratic strategist, Bustle Digital group head of research and Fox News contributor, Jessica Tarlov. Jessica, great to see you.

JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to see you. Thank you for having me. I'm at your set.

BARTIROMO: Although here again.

TARLOV: I know. We had to go far to talk about 2020.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. So what do you think is going on here? The president responding to AOC. She responds back. What's your reaction?

TARLOV: They've done that a few times before. AOC definitely likes to get into it with leading Republicans. She is making an argument that a number of Democrats have been making lately. But most of the ones who are doing it are from very safe districts. If you look at the bulk of where the party is, they're not in the impeachment camp, they're saying run on the issues, I heard you talking earlier with Andrew Napolitano about that as well. Saying get the job done, run on healthcare, talk about the economy, what we're going to do about criminal justice reform, gun safety measures, get him out of office and move on.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it seems like that would be the easiest thing and the right thing to do, given the fact that a lot of the metrics that you would use for a president's performance are very strong.

Let me bring Mitch and Cheryl in in New York right now. Because we keep talking about a great economy, decisions that many people are happy with and yet there's still this group of Democrats, Cheryl and Mitch, that want to impeach this president.

CASONE: They want to impeach him. They want Medicare for All. And then they're not paying attention to the role economic fundamentals that were seeing which are so positive, Maria. And you have to wonder if Democrats and these polls are saying they want somebody that's electable. Well, then you got to run on electable issue and it's not going after the big banks which they can't stop doing, you know, in appearance after appearance.

TARLOV: I'm not sure about this. You were just showing a graphic that shows a slight uptick in the interest in impeachment. And that's when the Fox News poll where there was another metric in there that showing -- show that economic comfort with the economy or economic outlook had actually gone down a bit from a couple months ago.

So I think that not every metric is going in the president's favor, obviously, in that arena but I still would say run on the issues. You can talk about impeachment, you can talk about obstruction of justice but that's not what motivates people to come out to the polls.

BARTIROMO: Have you decided who you're going to get behind on the Democratic field yet, Jessica?

TARLOV: I have three people but I am really -- would be thrilled with. And it's an exciting, huge field in. Debates are going to be wonderful.

But Joe Biden, Kamala Harris and Elizabeth Warren are top of the list for me now. So you have a moderate and kind of more extreme there with Elizabeth Warren but her surge has just been remarkable the past few weeks.

BARTIROMO: It really has been.

TARLOV: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Mitch, what about that? I mean, Elizabeth Warren, to see her in the number three spot behind Bernie and Joe Biden is pretty incredible, given that she's a progressive but very aggressive.

ROSCHELLE: And I think it will ultimately be a debate about the economy because some of her views which are, I'd call them anti-business are really sort of flying in the face of all of the growth that we've had in the economy that's been going on, you know, for the duration of the president's administration. So I think it's going to be a debate about whether or not business is the culprit or the reason for the growth in the economy.

TARLOV: I think Elizabeth Warren, Mayor Pete Buttigieg as well has been making a really effective argument for what they're calling just capitalism or Democratic capitalism. And it's actually quite similar to what President Trump campaigned on in 2016 where he talked about that the game was rigged against lower and middle class Americans. That message is resonating. Republicans need to be weary of it.

There was (INAUDIBLE) from the latest Quinnipiac poll that showed that there -- while people vote for the president was hand -- that the economy was doing well, they didn't give the president credit necessarily for that. So connecting those to dots is really going to be key for Republicans.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a good point. So you've got AOC again going after -- Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez going after Amazon, the Democrat bashing billionaire CEO Jeff Bezos. She said that Bezos is paying workers, quote, starvation wages. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JONATHAN KARL, CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT, ABC NEWS: Do you think that's why he's a billionaire, because he pays his workers starvation wages and --

OCASIO-CORTEZ: I think it's certainly part of the equation when you have a very large workforce and you underpay every single person. And then you also participate in -- you know, in taking billions of dollars of government subsidies. I think that could be part of it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Amazon is responding, by the way, and Amazon says, quote, these allegations are absurd. Amazon associates receive industry-leading pay starting at $15.00 an hour. Jessica, what do you make of it?

TARLOV: It didn't really work for her when she got Amazon booted out of the development in Long Island City.

ROSCHELLE: There you go.

BARTIROMO: That didn't work well at all.

TARLOV: No, that didn't play well with her fellow representatives, state representatives and mostly -- most importantly the constituents. This is a line of argumentation that a lot of Democrats are making.

I saw Amazon go after Joe Biden as well who's probably the most moderate of the bunch in here when he said they paid zero in corporate taxes. That's a good tact for AOC to be going with.

I think for Joe Biden long term, he's probably going to have to moderate on that, I think with the way that Amazon is certainly in everyone's lives. There's a very positive view of the company and if they can come up with data and say we're even paying, you know, $17.00 an hour in Arkansas, then they don't look so bad.

BARTIROMO: I mean, it was pretty much a black mark when she, you know, stopped Amazon from coming to New York, right, Mitch? I mean, why does she keep talking about Amazon?

ROSCHELLE: It's fascinating and let's not forget the jobs that were lost in New York were not $15.00 an hour jobs. They were six figure jobs that would have helped the local economy on Long Island City would have helped all of New York. So, there's a big disconnect between her view of them paying starvation wages and what they would have been paying people if they were in New York.

TARLOV: It's actually one of the strongest arguments people are making that she should have a primary challenger from the center, so do to her what she did to Joe Crowley just a couple years ago. I would imagine that she would get reelected. But it is an interesting conversation to be having since the justice Democrats, the far lefties love to get into races and kind of pick on moderates who are doing things to actually cater to their constituents.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's a good point because a lot of people say that right now she's trying to come up with challengers for Jerry Nadler and others. She wants her progressive candidates right in there. She wants to unseat all these moderates and Nadler's hardly a moderate, by the way.

TARLOV: No, going after Jerry Nadler is not smart. I mean, this is someone who's obviously the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, beloved in the party, he was my congressman all going through upset next to my mom in law school. So big fan of Jerry Nadler's. That's not a smart attack.

But she went after Dianne Feinstein. They pick on moderates or moderates all over the country. It brews and sews more discord than we need especially looking at 2020. Because it will be hard to unseat a sitting president. Just statically speaking, that doesn't happen that often.

BARTIROMO: But is this just one bridge too far? I mean, Cheryl, when I look at our audience, when I look at my friends, your friends, I feel like everyone's pretty much hanging out in the middle. I mean, you might lean to rot one, you know, to the right on some things you might lean to the left on other things but the majority of the country is hanging out in the middle. And so, I don't understand why we give so much attention to the extremists like an AOC when in fact that's not where the country is. Does she not see that?

CASONE: Well, she obviously is not looking at the most recent polling that we've seen Maria, which shows that within likely Democratic voters, the number one thing they want, electability. And that at this point, if you look at the polls is Joe Biden, it is not Bernie Sanders. It's definitely not AOC's ideas which is kind of half of Bernie Sanders' platform right now.

So, at this point -- you know, electability and they're still talking about healthcare, those are the two things they should focus on. The impeachment thing needs to go.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I'll tell you, Joe Biden is keeping a low profile isn't he?

TARLOV: He had a really bad week last week. I think he'll be out more, there's a big event in South Carolina over the weekend where he will definitely be attending. But he's doing well at the Fox News poll was really good for him as Cheryl said on the electability question. I think he's running a really good campaign. We should also pay attention to the fact that AOC hasn't endorsed yet. She was a Bernie girl in 2016. A lot of people think she's eyeing Elizabeth Warren potentially as her progressive candidate versus Bernie.

BARTIROMO: By the way, I would have thought President Obama would be -- you know, supporting Joe Biden but not happening.

TARLOV: No, he and Michele said months and months ago, there are too many people in the race, when you have 23 candidates. And they have -- you know, very good relationship with at least 10 of them. It would be unfair to do that, even if there are friendship bracelets in the mix.

BARTIROMO: Jessica, good to see you.

TARLOV: It was great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Jessica, thank you.

TARLOV: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Jessica Tarlov here in Cannes with me. We will take a short break. When we come back, Bitcoin is taking off this morning, the cryptocurrency topping $9,000 on reports Facebook maybe launching its own digital money.

Then, Maria mix-up, one person's a pop star, another pioneer scientist mixed up at the bakery. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A merger in the drug industry to report. Lauren Simonetti with headlines right now in New York, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Maria. Another oncology takeover, the Biotech Company set to acquire Array Biopharma for a deal worth about $11.4 billion. The transaction will be done using stock valued at $48.00 a share. Array's portfolio includes cancer fighting drugs and you can see share reaction, Array shares surging 60 percent this morning.

Well, Bitcoin surging again. It climbed above $9,300 over the weekend after Facebook announced plans for its own cryptocurrency. Investors say the number of companies signing up for Facebook system is restoring confidence in digital money.

Mariah, Marie, the names causing a bit of a mix-up at a bakery in England. A woman named Siobhan asked a coworker for a birthday cake with Mariah Carey's face on it. Well, they tried. The cake reportedly arriving with a picture of the Nobel Prize winner Marie Curie. She won the prize in 1903 for her work in radiation. The cake shown off in a tweet by Siobhan's cousin has racked up more than 200,000 likes. A notable woman nonetheless, Maria.

BARTIROMO: And very different looking than Mariah Carey.

SIMONETTI: You think?

BARTIROMO: It was funny.

SIMONETTI: Sparking some scientific tweets.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Lauren. Coming up, Gary Woodland winning the U.S. Open, what led to his surprise victory, we've got sports coming up right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. From Sunny Cannes, France, here, we are looking at sports this morning. Brooks Koepka quest for U.S. Open history in sunny California. Jared Max joins us now with more, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX SPORTS NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria. Brooks Koepka earned a check for $1.35 million yesterday for second place. The winner's check for $2.25 million went to 35-year-old Gary Woodland from Topeka, Kansas. First time on tour. He did not peak too soon. Offers have a lifetime when leading after 54 holes, Woodland held off Koepka by three shots. His first major win. Koepka the first ever to shoot all four rounds in the 60s at the U.S. Open and not win. Tiger Woods tied for 21st, 11 shots back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GARY WOODLAND, GOLFER: It means everything especially, you know, being in America, we have men and women that go out and fight and serve and sacrifice for us to go out and here and play a game. I was able to come play a game at Pebble Beach and walk away U.S. Open champion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Proud American. It was a record setting Sunday for U.S. Women's National Soccer star Carli Lloyd, 36 years old, she became the oldest player to score twice in a Women's World Cup match. And after Carli's first goal, well, she took a funny shot at those critics who said team USA celebrated too much in winning 13-0. This time a sarcastic golf clap from Carli Lloyd. The next match will be Thursday against Sweden.

And 30 minutes from now, Maria's going to talk to former U.S. soccer stars and Fox Sports analyst Aly Wagner and Alexi Lalas. This coming up at 8:20 a.m. Eastern Time.

Did you see how much money somebody paid for a jersey worn by Babe Ruth circa 1928 to 1930? This jersey worn by the Babe at the time he earned $70-80,000 in annual salary purchased at auction for $5.64 million. Via that's more than $1.2 million more than the previous record for sports memorabilia.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAVE HUNT, PRESIDENT, HOT AUCTIONS: There's only about six of these known of any equality. This is from that late 20s, that murder Israel era. And you see just the beautiful condition, original Yankees across front which is interestingly the only time in their history that that franchise name was across their jersey,

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: And look at that, the estimate was $4.5 million when David Hunt from Hunt's auction spoke with MORNINGS WITH MARIA. $5.64 million, a lot of money Maria for a piece of laundry.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible. And we -- and we were -- we were awe -- in awe of it when he came and he brought the jersey on-set and now we see, wow, we underestimated the value.

MAX: I wonder is that the same one George Costanza wore to work when he put on the U.S. trying to get himself fired. Maybe a little jam on it herself then don't wear it to work.

BARTIROMO: Oh, my God. That's funny. Jared, thank you.

MAX: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Catch Jared sports reports on Fox News Headlines, 24/7 or on Radio, Sirius Radio XM 115.

We'll slip in a short break, and then the Trump economy. Former Reagan economic advisor Art Laffer is here on trade tensions with China and what new Fox News polls are saying now about the perception of the economy, next hour, right here, MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Stay with us.

ANNOUNCER: Live from France at the 2019 Cannes Lions, here's Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

BARTIROMO: Good Monday morning live from beautiful Cannes. It is Monday June 17th. thanks for joining us. Your top stories right now, 08:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets this morning are holding on to gains headed toward the open, although it is a fractional move and it has been back and forth for Futures this morning. Take a look, Dow Futures right now spiking up 37 points this is the highest of the morning right here. The S&P Futures are up 4-3/4 point and the NASDAQ Futures higher by 23.

Friday markets ended the day down slightly but up for the entire week. Of course --

urn:contentItem:5WJB-DPY1-F15W-H0Y6-00000-00President Donald Trump Delivers Remarks at the Presidential Social Media Summit2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:18ZLexisNexisPresident Donald Trump Delivers Remarks at the Presidential Social Media Summit

President Donald Trump Delivers Remarks At The Presidential Social Media Summit

July 11, 2019 03:45 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP (R-N.Y.)

SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO.)

LAWYER HARMEET DHILLON

LIVE ACTION FOUNDER LILA ROSE

[*]TRUMP: Thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

Thank you. Thank you very much. Thank you. Please sit down. I want to thank you all for being here. Very special day, very important day. Many of you are friends and many of you are friends that I don't know what you look like but I know what you sound like--

(LAUGHTER)

--which I guess is probably more important, right? But I want to thank you and it's a terrific--it's a terrific day to be together and if you look you are in a very famous place. We all work very hard and I don't know if you call it influence, I don't if you call it power but whatever it is we are in the White House and we are going to stay in the White House and we are going to get our agenda done and completed beautifully.

(APPLAUSE)

(INAUDIBLE). So I am thrilled to welcome you here and we are all working very hard and I don't if you know but we just hit 27,000 on the Dow, that's the highest in history. We are up a couple of hundred points today.

(APPLAUSE)

The highest in history for those of you that like the stock market. The stock market means jobs; I view it as jobs and I view it as 401(k)s. When the people say oh, the rich people are getting rich but if you look at the numbers the greatest impact proportionately is blue-collar workers in what is happened in this miracle that is happening.

(APPLAUSE)

And people with 401(k)s, they are up 72 percent and 67 percent and the wife or the husband whoever is responsible the other one says you're a genius, you're a great financial investor. Darling you're up 77 percent this year. So a lot of good things happen. A lot of people are happy and I think really everybody is happy, some people just aren't willing to admit it. Does that make sense?

(LAUGHTER)

So this is a historic day. Never before have so many online journalist and influencers and that is exactly what you are, you are journalists and you are influencers come together in this building to discuss the future of social media.

Each of you is fulfilling a vital role in our nation. You are challenging the media gatekeepers in the corporate sensors to bring the facts straight to the American people and that is what you are doing. You were going right to the people possibly we wouldn't be here right now. I asked somebody what do you think I would do without social media? Would I be here because I said I think so but they weren't so sure.

(LAUGHTER)

I have to say that you know that. I'm not sure I believe that but I have to say it.

But you communicate directly with our citizens without having to go through the fake news filter, very simple. Together you reach more people than any television, broadcast network by far, not even close. We are delighted to be joined at the summit by someone you know very well, our senior advisor for digital strategy and somebody that has been working for me for a long time, for many years, Dan Scavino. Where is Dan?

(APPLAUSE)

Stand up. So long before we were even doing this he was at a club, running a club and other businesses and he was okay at doing it, not the greatest. I wouldn't say the greatest but you know what he was great at, he was always looking at his computer screen. I said that guy's incredible so right at the beginning I said that the man and there's nobody better at that and I think Hillary had 28 people and I had Dan.

(LAUGHTER)

(APPLAUSE)

Right?

(APPLAUSE)

I had my Dan and he works at about 28 hours a day and he works very hard. He doesn't work. I mean he loves it. He loves it. And his imagination and really working with all of you and many of you will come up with ideas and you will come up with ideas and he will run into my office and so you got to see this. And a lot of times I will go out I will spend a lot of money on a concept. I will say here's a concept come up with this and we will hire these companies and they want a lot of money and they come back, just happened the other day, right? I said that's terrible; these guys have no talent. The people that have a talent are the people that we deal with and it's true and some of you are extraordinary. Can't say everybody.

(LAUGHTER)

No, but some of you are extraordinary. The crap you think of is unbelievable.

(LAUGHTER)

(APPLAUSE)

Unbelievable. So I'm going to go back to the basics of Washington. I'm going to introduce some of my secretaries. Steve Mnuchin. Where Steve? Steve has done a fantastic job.

(APPLAUSE)

Wilbur Ross. Wilbur. We have a meeting in a little while on the census and citizenship. Can you believe are you a citizen of the United States of America. Sir, you can't ask that question.

(LAUGHTER)

Why? Because the court said you can't. We have three very unfriendly courts. They fight us all of the way; the judges don't like us too much I guess. But think of that. Herman(SP), think of that question. Are you a citizen? We spend--this is another thing that so crazy $20 billion on a census, $20 billion, they spent $20 billion. I said 20 billion what? $20 billion on a census.

They go through houses. They go up, they ring doorbells, they talk to people. How many toilets do they have? How many desks, how many beds, what is their roof made of?

(LAUGHTER)

The only thing we can't ask is are you a citizen of the United States. Is that the craziest thing?

(APPLAUSE)

$20 billion. Pretty amazing. Pretty amazing, Charlie(SP).

Also David Bernhardt, great job you are doing, interiors. He's the largest landlord in the United States. When my friends tell me how big they are--I just bought another building. Big deal Kevin(SP), right? They bought another building. Then I look at David Bernhardt he controls half of the United States; Department of Interiors, a lot of land, a lot of beautiful and that we are taking good care of, David, right?

Acting Director Russ Vought. Russ, thank you. Great job.

(APPLAUSE)

We are working on our budget along with some of the great members of Congress and wonderful friend of mine who's my leader, right? He's my leader. I tell him that to his face because it makes him feel good. I don't know if I believe that Marshall(SP) but Kevin, stand up, Kevin. Kevin McCarthy everybody.

(APPLAUSE)

Senator Marsha Blackburn of the great state of Tennessee; we campaigned together.

(APPLAUSE)

And she (INAUDIBLE), we can say it now, she ran against the most popular Democrat in the last 50 years, he really was good man, right? And Governor for quite a long time, eight years and she just didn't stop.

UNKNOWN: (INAUDIBLE)

TRUMP: She was down by 10 and she won by 12.

(APPLAUSE)

That's right. She was down by 10 and she won by 12 and she wouldn't stop. Every day, where is she? She's here, she's there. Fantastic job you did we are proud of you. Well, thank you, honey. That's great. It was just honestly working with people that know what they are doing it's fun. That was fun and you know what you are doing.

Representative Dan Crenshaw who was very good at this by the way, Dan, very good at this, really good. Thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

It's great to have you in the party and you have more courage than I do, Dan. Okay. That courage of yours is incredible. Thank you very much. Great job.

A friend of mine and a wonderful person and somebody that has I don't know pretty unlimited future I would say. I hear a lot of very positive things, Liz Cheney. Liz, thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

And you know I pardoned somebody named Scooter Libby. A lot of you don't know who Scooter Libby is, Scooter Libby is a man that got treated very unfairly and Liz was right in the forefront of that one and I said what do you think Liz and you said absolutely he deserves it and it's been a very popular pardon. He was treated very, very brutally and unfairly. So thank you for that, for that help.

Matt Gaetz, where is Matt? Stand up, Matt.

(APPLAUSE)

Boy, a great defender he gets on television and he's like it doesn't stop and he's smart and he's good and he loves Florida and he loves his people and he's a hard worker. And Matt thank you very much. I really appreciate it very much. And Mike Johnson. Mike, thank you. Great job, Mike.

(APPLAUSE)

And I want to thank a man who I said a long time ago when we said let's do it because Josh Hawley is special. He is somebody that I said Josh you got to run. Well, I don't know. You know he had a good set up pretty well, right? I'll tell you, I'm dealing with China and they admitted there's nobody like Silicon Valley. There's nobody smart in that sense, may be not smart and other senses, I've watched some of them speak before Congress, it's not pretty.

(LAUGHTER)

I said I could do much better than that.

(LAUGHTER)

But I'll tell you what, technologically, it's unbelievable what they think of. Even Dan and I, when we sat with you know who at Twitter, number one--

(LAUGHTER)

We talked about certain things. He said, "Yeah, we could do this, this, this." I said "That's really great. You know, this is incredible stuff." China will admit there's nobody like these brains, but they are not using that brilliance and they're not using what we gave them fairly and they have to do that. And we don't want to stifle anything. We certainly don't want to stifle free speech, but that's no longer free speech. See, I don't think that the mainstream media is free speech either because it's so crooked. It's so dishonest.

So to me, free speech is not when you see something good and then you purposely write bad. To me, that's a very dangerous speech, and you become angry at it. But that's not free speech. Some it came to my office, I won't say who, but a very big person and I said, "Okay, you don't like the term fake news," which I think I get credit for, but I'm sure if I said that I get credit, they'd say, "13 years ago someone to come up with that term fake--"

(LAUGHTER)

I think I get credit. I'd be very proud to take it, but I think I get credit. Now, by the way, the worst fakers of all are using fake news. I saw the other day on CNN, total fakes, I see on CNN they go, "Fake news media has reported." No, no, no, they are fake news media.

(LAUGHTER)

They've turned it around.

(LAUGHTER)

They turned it around. So I'm not going to allow, and Josh and all of us, we're just not going to allow it to happen like this. We're not going to be silenced. Two months ago, we created a new White House tool to report social media bias, censorship, and discrimination. We saw you folks being taken off and we fought on all of you and many of you are back now. But many of the names I won't mention your names, some--some of you were taken off for absolutely no reason. I mean, in all fairness, some of you I could almost understand.

(LAUGHTER)

I mean, some of you guys are out there.

(LAUGHTER)

But even you should have a voice.

(APPLAUSE)

But some of you--no, some of you deserve--some of you.

(APPLAUSE)

I mean, it's genius, but it's bad.

(LAUGHTER)

But they take off people that, you know, that you wouldn't believe. And we received over 16,000 responses just in a tiny little period of time talking about this subject. Based on the feedback that we are hearing from you, I'm announcing that we will ask representatives of the major social media platforms to join me at the White House over the next month, have a big meeting at a real conversation. We might want to invite some of you. I know Josh, we're going to have you and some of the senators.

And it's amazing how the senators, including Democrats, in all fairness, which is probably--because I know it can turn on them also, it could turn very quickly. But they want to come, so we'll let you know the date, okay? And today, I'm directing my administration to explore all regulatory and legislative solutions to protect free speech and the free speech rights of all Americans. That's you people in this room, and a lot of people out there. There are a lot of people.

We hope to see transparency, more accountability, and more freedom. That's on both sides. This is not--I am not speaking for our side assuming we're all--I don't even know if you're on our side. You could be some of the most liberal people in the world in this audience and that's okay. I don't care. But we're talking about for everybody.

Big tech must not censor the voices of the American people. To all of the social media influencers here today, a lot of--you have a lot of power and you have a lot of strength. As you know, you have to use it wisely. Many of you do, but you have to. I want to thank you once again for being here. You're very special people. You're very brilliant people in so many cases. I look around the room. I mean, I see people that really have almost found a new life of the last short period of time with his new technology. But this new technology is so powerful and so important, and it has to be used fairly. It has to be used fairly.

So thank you all for being here, it's a great honor, a tremendous honor. We're going to take a few questions, I think, and then I'll head out and you're going to actually come, if you want. You can come to the great Rose Garden. You can stand in the rain with me. We're going to talk a little bit about the fact that we are not allowed to ask for whether or not somebody is a citizen on the census form, and I think we have a solution that will be very good for a lot of people. Really good. Okay, any questions? Please. Oh, there he is. There's my guy.

QUESTION: Thank you, Mr. President

TRUMP: Good job. How is your new show going? Good?

QUESTION: Very well, thank you.

TRUMP: I heard good.

QUESTION: Thank you. Yes, indeed. America First, Salem Radio Network, Sebastian Gawker (PH). We have half a billion people that we can access with you as well, and we thank you for the role that you played--

TRUMP: --Thank you--

QUESTION: --In making sure that they try and stop throttling us--

TRUMP: --That's okay. Don't worry. Fake news.

(LAUGHTER)

There trying to--they are trying to divert your attention.

QUESTION: What--what message would you--

TRUMP: --They're playing with your mind, Sebastian.

(LAUGHTER)

That doesn't work too well with you. Let's go.

QUESTION: It doesn't work with people in this room. What message would you have us send to our followers about what's being done to them and the importance of this issue for 2020? Because a lot of people out there who call into my show don't want to use their real name, are afraid of putting their--their views up on the internet.

President Donald Trump Holds Media Availability With Tech Workers, As Released By The White House

August 03, 2020 11:30 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP (R-FLA.)

U.S. TECH WORKERS, PENNSYLVANIA FOUNDER KEVIN LYNN

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY, GEORGIA SERVICE MANAGEMENT IT OPERATIONS ENGINEER STACY WHETZELL

ENGINEERING ASSOCIATION, TENNESSEE PRESIDENT GAY HENSON

REP. TIM BURCHETT (R-TENN.)

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY RELIABILITY AND PERFORMANCE IT OPERATIONS ENGINEER DAVID LITTLEJOHN

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY, TENNESSEE ENTERPRISE RESOURCE PLANNING SOFTWARE ENGINEER WENDY TURNER

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY, TENNESSEE DISASTER RECOVERY ADMINISTRATOR CHUCK CHARNAWSKAS

SECRETARY OF LABOR EUGENE SCALIA

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY, ALABAMA IT END USER ANALYST LINDA MCDONALD

TENNESSEE ENGINEERING ASSOCIATION SPECIALIST RENAE MCKENZIE

DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY ACTING DEPUTY SECRETARY KEN CUCCINELLI

PROTECT US WORKERS, FLORIDA PRESIDENT SARA BLACKWELL

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY SOFTWARE ENGINEER JONATHAN HICKS

VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE (R-IND.)

[*]TRUMP: Well, thank you very much. And today I'm signing an executive order to ensure that the federal government lives by a very simple rule: Hire American. We've been doing it at a level that hasn't been done maybe ever.

I'll also be taking firm, disciplinary action against the leadership of the Tennessee Valley Authority, which has sadly and cruelly betrayed American workers. And we have some of those great American workers with us at the table. This is the Cabinet Room, and it's an honor to have you in the Cabinet Room and at the Oval Office.

We're joined by the Vice President; Congressman Tim Burchett, who's doing a fantastic job in the state of Tennessee; Secretary of Labor Eugene Scalia; Acting Deputy Secretary of Homeland Secretary, Ken Cuccinelli. Where's Ken? Hi, Ken. I didn't see you down there. That's great. Doing a great job.

CUCCINELLI: Quiet, as usual.

TRUMP: Keep you busy, right?

(LAUGHTER.)

We're keeping you busy, Ken.

Recently, the CEO of the Tennessee Valley Authority, Jeffrey Lyash, made a disastrous and heartless decision. The TVA announced that it would lay off over 200 American workers and replace them with cheaper foreign workers brought in from overseas.

The Tennessee Valley Authority leadership then ordered the American workers to train their foreign replacements, rubbing salt in their very open wound.

So we're going to bring in workers. They're going to foreign workers. And people from Tennessee, and some others states right around it, are going to train them -- what to do and how to do it. It doesn't work that way.

As we speak, we're finalizing H1-B regulations so that no American worker is replaced ever again. H1-Bs should be used for top, highly paid talent to create American jobs, not as inexpensive labor program to destroy American jobs.

Sitting at the table are six of the TVA workers who were ordered to train the foreign labor flown in to replace them. I want you and your colleagues to know that my administration will not be putting up with -- I happen to know a young woman who's been very active over the last couple of years because we were together on Disney and a couple of other things.

BLACKWELL: Yes. Yes, sir. Yes, sir.

TRUMP: And it all seems to be working out pretty well.

BLACKWELL: Thank you so much.

TRUMP: You're doing a great job.

BLACKWELL: Thank you.

TRUMP: And thank you for it.

But that's why I'm formally removing the chairman of the board, James Thompson, and board member Richard Howorth. If the TVA does not move swiftly to reverse their decision to rehire their workers, then more board members will be removed. We have the absolute right to remove board members. And the board makes the decision; I don't make the decision. I saw there was an ad on television talking about the amount of money that the chairman makes, and it's a ridiculous amount of money. But we have the right to replace the board, and the board is the one -- the only ones that get the right to then hire a new person.

Furthermore, the board must immediately hire that new CEO who puts the interest of American workers first. The current CEO, Jeff Lyash, is ridiculously overpaid. He earns $8 million a year. Did you know that? Eight million. He's the highest-paid government official of any country anywhere in the world.

Now, I don't know that you call him officially a "government." It might be a public-private. It may be something -- a lot time ago, it was established, Tennessee Valley Authority. But he gets $8 million a year. So that was just a succession of deep-swamp things happening, and it's a disgrace. But he gets $8 million a year, and I can think of about almost 100 percent of the people I know would take that job.

(LAUGHTER.)

It's not a very hard job. I mean, you have not a lot of debt, not a lot of anything, right?

Public service is just that: Those who takes these jobs must be focused on the public good, not on personal profit. He would have taken the job for millions and millions of dollars less, but nobody asked him to do that. Okay? He would have gone for less. You could have had him for $4 million, $6 million, $7 million, $2 million, $1 million, probably $500,000 a year.

But the new CEO must be paid no more than $500,000 a year, which is still a significant amount more than the President of the United States makes. And I donate my salary. I've donated it. From what I hear, I'm the only President to do that. You'll have to check on that, but that's what I've heard. I'm very surprised to hear that. But I donate my full salary; I don't take it.

The board must work to ensure the CEO does not receive a lavish compensation package upon his departure, too. We don't want him leaving and then he gets a big check for millions and millions of dollars.

We want the TVA to take action on this immediately: Lower energy prices in the states of Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia. I love all those states. Any additional states you can think of there? I don't know. Let's see. So we're talking about of Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia. Great states, there -- every one of them.

So let this serve as a warning to any federally appointed board. If you betray American workers, then you will hear two simple words: "You're fired." "You're fired." It's ridiculous. The man is getting $8 million. It'd be interesting to see how much money he made before this. And I have no idea. Maybe he made more. I don't know. But I doubt it. But it'd be interesting to see. He got this position -- must have been politically inspired because I can think of probably, almost, everybody in the nation would have liked this position, including every one of the media folks across the table from me. I would say that everybody would have liked this position.

So, with that, we're getting rid of him in one form or another. Either the board is going to do it, we're going to do it. But he's gone. And he's done not a great job. He's done not even a good job, in certain ways. Plants in Kentucky -- he could've kept the plant open in Kentucky, if he wanted to, even if they retrofitted the plant. And he didn't do that, did he, Congressman?

BURCHETT: No, sir.

TRUMP: He wouldn't do that.

BURCHETT: No, sir.

TRUMP: We asked him to do it. He didn't want to do it. We said, "That's okay." And here we are doing what we're doing today.

So we will get somebody for a much lower price. I want the saving -- much lower salary -- I want the saving to go to the people of these great states in the form of energy savings. And that's a pretty substantial number.

So, Kevin, could I ask you to start off and say a few words, please?

LYNN: I certainly appreciate that, Mr. President. My name is Kevin Lynn. I'm the executive director of Progressives for Immigration Reform and the founder of U.S. Tech Workers. And thank you for paying attention to our ad, Mr. President.

We were founded -- we founded U.S. Tech Workers three years ago to look at the -- and inform the public on the great harm that's being caused by the outsourcing and offshoring of our skilled labor jobs. And, Mr. President, I want to thank you for inviting us here. On behalf of U.S. Tech Workers and the Tennessee Valley Authority, we appreciate your willingness to look at the endangered jobs of the Tennessee Valley Authority workers, especially in a time of pandemic and an election year, when you've been so busy signing documents that affect the welfare of millions of Americans.

Taking time to ensure that these hundreds of workers, under your administration, can continue to provide great services to the American people, as they have since 1933, shows the people of Tennessee and beyond that you stand by your promise to keep American jobs with Americans.

This is a historic moment that I'm hopeful will reverse the harm outsourcing and offshoring have done to our nation's productive classes. And it is my hope that Congress will join you, Mr. President, in making sure our workers are more secure in their jobs.

TRUMP: Good.

LYNN: Thank you, Mr. President.

TRUMP: So you're the one that took the ad about me that -- I didn't know that.

(LAUGHTER.)

I was just saying, you know, "I think he's the one that took this, really, vicious ad." Like, I hired this guy for $8 million, that I had nothing to do with it. I said, "What's that?" But, actually, you brought something very important up, because when I looked into it, I said, "This guy is actually making $8 million a year." And you did the ad. So you really made me aware of what was going on with the Tennessee Valley Authority, which has been a -- a feeding pot for a long time. And a lot of deep state, a lot of swamp creatures, okay?

So, that's it. So we're going to make that -- I see. So I think now you realize that it wasn't about me. I hope you now realize that.

LYNN: I do realize that, Mr. President.

(LAUGHTER.)

But if I could --

TRUMP: I accept -- I accept your apology.

(LAUGHTER.)

LYNN: In full disclosure, Mr. President, when we sat down with the Davis Agency constructing the ad, they said, "Who's your audience?" And I said, "Just one person. He's the only one that..." --

TRUMP: That's smart.

(LAUGHTER.)

LYNN: -- "...would do this, and he's the only one that can come to the aid of these workers in the Tennessee Valley."

BURCHETT: He's the only one with any guts to do it -- who has guts to do it.

TRUMP: I'll tell you, though -- I have to say, Kevin, the end was very appropriate. And while it has nothing to do with me, I can do things with respect to the board, and ultimately, the board controls that decision. This is a very, very old authority done in the --

LYNN: 1933, Mr. President.

TRUMP: So it was done during the FDR days. And it's been -- you know, it's been getting crazier and crazier just over the years. And they have, basically, nobody watching over them. And the board isn't watching. You see this happening in public companies also. You see it happening a lot.

But for a essentially -- I would say, for a federal employee to be paid $8 million -- now what we're doing is we're looking at the board members, how much are they paid. Because usually what happens is they pay, and then he says, "You know, I think you ought to get more money." And everybody is making a lot of money, and your pricing for electric and utilities starts going up, and people say, "I wonder why."

I also see that they're doing a lot of things in terms of electric, which is very expensive electric. They're building facilities that are very, very expensive to build and don't work well. But we'll discuss that separately.

But I appreciate it because you did make me aware of what's going on, and it's a terrific thing we're doing today. Thank you very much, Kevin.

Please, Stacy. How are you?

WHETZELL: I'm doing fine. Mr. President, my name is Stacy Whetzell. I'm the son of a sharecropper.

First, I want to thank you for being the great American President you are and for caring about and looking out for the great American citizens and workers. We thank you for that.

I picked cotton from the time I was big enough to carry my own pick sack until I married. My wife and I have been married 47 years and have 7 children and 14 grandchildren. I began working for TVA in 1975 as a carpenter's apprentice. Currently, I'm the system administrator on TVA's core team that's responsible for installing a $20 million computer system. Our team and the entire IT department have been praised and thanked multiple times this summer for the outstanding performance we've done.

So it was shocking and devastating to be notified on July the 23rd that IT leadership had decided our team and a total of 40 workers would be terminated and our work done to others. This brings the total planned outsourced jobs to over 200 in TVA information technology alone. We believe there are more planned to come.

The three companies chosen to do the IT work are all three foreign companies that depend heavily on H1-B workers. We're required to train these -- our replacements, as President Trump said. Apparently, we're good enough to train but not retain.

Using H1-B workers to replace capable and willing American citizens is turning entire American communities upside down. Left unchecked, it will turn our nation upside down and negatively impact our national security as certainly as our 50-year build-up of dependence on China for manufacturing has. Thank you, President Trump, for beginning to reverse that hive-centric mistake.

American patriots will forever be grateful that you're also acting and fought the misguided and out-of-control H1-B worker program. I thank you for Americans first and acting to stop this travesty.

TRUMP: Well, you're a very powerful speaker. And so powerful that we just got a call -- Mark just brought this in from -- the TVA CEO, and he's indicated a very strong willingness to reverse course.

(LAUGHTER AND APPLAUSE.)

So it must have been Stacy. I think Stacy did a much better job than me. I mean, you're talking and all of the sudden, I get the note.

So he's looking to change course and reverse it, and that's good. Now, maybe he'll take a major cut in salary, too. That'll be phase two, right? So we'll take a look at that. And maybe you'll start looking at that on behalf of everybody, gratis. Right?

HENSON: Yes, sir.

TRUMP: Your group. That's great, isn't it.

HENSON: Yeah, I mean, TVA told me while we were in this process of working on behalf of the workers -- I'm the union president, IFPTE-Engineering Association. They told me it's going to take a message -- a stop order from the President in order to keep us from moving forward. And I said, "I'm working on that."

(LAUGHTER.)

TRUMP: And you did a good job.

HENSON: So I appreciate you.

TRUMP: Everybody in this room did a good job.

HENSON: I appreciate you, sir.

TRUMP: And, Congressman, you have my endorsement.

BURCHETT: Thank you, Mr. President.

TRUMP: Okay? You had it anyway, but you have it now. It's a great job.

BURCHETT: Well, I appreciate you.

TRUMP: The only congressman in the room. I tell you, Tim, great job.

BURCHETT: Thank you, brother.

TRUMP: That's only phase one. Phase two is -- imagine being paid the $8 million a year to run a thing that's pretty easy to run, in all fairness. It's not like he built it; he didn't build it. He went there and he's been there, and he gets a lot of money, and it shouldn't be. Five hundred thousand dollars is a lot of money, right?

BURCHETT: Yes, sir. In Tennessee, it is.

TRUMP: And I'm willing to say he gets paid more money than I do. I don't care.

BURCHETT: Yes, sir.

TRUMP: But, you know, it shouldn't happen.

So that's a start. That's a start. And I think we should find out what board members make, okay? Because --

BURCHETT: I'll look into that.

TRUMP: -- I can almost guarantee you they're paid heavily.

Congratulations, Stacy. Really good.

Please, go ahead.

LITTLEJOHN: Yes, sir. Mr. President, thank you. My name is David Littlejohn. I am a soon-to-be father. This November, my wife will be giving birth to my first child. I am a long line -- I'm the son in a long line of military men and women, so I was born with a heart of service. And with that, I love to serve the people of the Valley.

I was told July 23rd that I would be sent home and to be trained -- training a contractor from a H1-B-dependent contract company. Now, I'm shaking right now because --

TRUMP: You're doing great.

LITTLEJOHN: Thank you.

TRUMP: You had a big victory already.

(LAUGHTER.)

LITTLEJOHN: Yes, sir.

I'm shaking right now because this really impacts me and my wife and my unborn child, and I greatly appreciate everyone here to support us.

TRUMP: I appreciate it, and thank you very much.

LITTLEJOHN: Yes, sir.

TRUMP: And you'll see what happens. It's going to be very quick, too. Thank you.

Wendy, please.

TURNER: Yeah. I'm Wendy Turner, and thank you for having us here. I've been a software engineer at TVA for 19 years. I'm going to change my comments a little. I was (INAUDIBLE) saying, you know, for the first time in 19 years, I didn't know what was going to happen to me and my kids, and I also take care of my mom. But what we're going to do going forward -- so, thank you.

TRUMP: And this was -- everybody felt this way in Tennessee Valley Authority then, I guess-- right? -- if you do. You've been there for 19 years. So everyone had to feel this way, like there's been a big feeling of doubt, right?

TURNER: Right. Yeah.

TRUMP: That's a terrible thing.

TURNER: Yeah.

TRUMP: They're waiting for it to happen to them.

TURNER: Yeah, and I've been training since June. I've been training our replacements from a company that relied on --

TRUMP: You've been training people?

TURNER: Yes. Yes, sir.

TRUMP: And so, did they let you off yet? Or are you not sure?

TURNER: I got my notice in June that we would be laid off September 1st.

TRUMP: So you're training people to take your job at a -- whatever. Right?

TURNER: They told us it would be --

TRUMP: And where are the people from that you're training?

TURNER: All over the place. We -- everything is done remotely or --

TRUMP: Are they from other countries?

TURNER: They're here on soil now. I don't know their status as far as --

TRUMP: Because with Disney, they were from other countries, right?

HENSON: Yes, sir.

TRUMP: Go ahead.

TURNER: Yeah, so I don't know. I know the com- -- Accenture is replacing our group, and I know they rely heavily on H1-B workers, but I don't know for sure where everyone is.

TRUMP: Okay. Well, we'll make sure that things work out for the three of them because they're brave to be here, actually, Sara. So you'll check that out, right?

BLACKWELL: Yes, sir.

TRUMP: Let's see that they get their jobs back --

TURNER: Thank you very much.

TRUMP: -- because I hear you're great workers. I mean, I said I want people, but I also people that are really good workers -- that did a great job. Because, you know, people can be let go; should be able to -- if they're not doing a good job. I'm all for that. I think -- I'll bet you are.

But I said, "I want people that really do a great job and were unfairly let go." Right, Tim?

BURCHETT: Absolutely.

TRUMP: That's, to me, very important.
