BLACKWELL: My son, actually, who's 11.

TRUMP: Your son? He's 11?

BLACKWELL: Yes.

TRUMP: If he's 11, and he said he's slow and that he shouldn't be President --

BURCHETT: They need to pay your son $15 million in consulting.

(LAUGHTER.)

TRUMP: Great job.

BLACKWELL: Actually, during the rallies in 2016, you met my son. He had a Thor, and he dressed him up like President Trump.

TRUMP: Oh, that's great.

BLACKWELL: Yes. Thank you.

TRUMP: That's very nice. Thank you, Sara. Very -- great job you're doing.

BLACKWELL: Thank you so much. Thank you.

TRUMP: Good. Thank you.

BLACKWELL: Thank you for all you do.

TRUMP: Okay, Mike. Go ahead. We'll knock it out, Sara.

PENCE: Well, thank you, Mr. President. I'll be -- I'll just be very brief.

Four years ago, when you ran for this office, you said the forgotten men and women in America would be forgotten no more. You said that we'd put America first and American workers first, you said that American workers would have a seat at the table in this administration, and we'd deliver real results.

And today, we see all that happen right in front of us. Because of your leadership indicated during this meeting, that the TVA is going to reverse course on their plan to use H1-B visa workers to replace hardworking Americans. And I can see the gratitude and the emotion on faces around the room, Mr. President, and the gratitude that these people feel and all those that will be reading about this and hearing about this in the days ahead.

But I also just want to say, finally, to all the -- all the great Americans who gathered here, who have been willing to speak up: Know that with the executive order the President is signing today, we're not just solving your problem. What the President is committing to today is to end the abuse of our worker visa program once and for all, and pulling together multiple agencies to do that. And I want to promise you that you've not only gone out and been a champion for fellow workers at TVA, but you've been champions for American workers all across this country.

And I know I speak on behalf of the President and our whole administration when I thank you. Thank you for stepping up for American workers and making it possible for this President to keep one more promise to working Americans. God bless you.

(APPLAUSE.)

TRUMP: Thank you. So we're going to sign a little document now. Is that okay?

BLACKWELL: I would love that. Thank you, President Trump.

TRUMP: And it's very important one, aligning federal contractors and contracting and hiring practices with the interests of the American workers, which is very simple -- which actually just boils down to pretty much what we're talking about today. Okay?

BLACKWELL: Thank you so much, President Trump.

(THE EXECUTIVE ORDER IS SIGNED.)

TRUMP: Here, give that to Sara because she was there very early. (DISTRIBUTES SIGNING PEN.)

BLACKWELL: Thank you so much.

TRUMP: I have to give -- I have to give one to you. You got us moving here. That's good. Will you pass these around the table, Mike? We'll just pass them on that side. You'll pass them on this side. Everybody that doesn't get it -- (DISTRIBUTES SIGNING PENS.)

So here we are.

BURCHETT: (INAUDIBLE.)

TRUMP: Yeah, I'll get you one, Tim. Don't worry.

So, thank you very much everybody.

(APPLAUSE.)

We're going to be -- we're going to be discussing, very shortly, a immigration bill, which covers this and many other things. It'll be a very, very comprehensive bill. That's a word that some people love and some people hate, but it'll be very comprehensive only in the sense that it'll cover just about everything.

It'll be based on merit. It will be -- it'll cover territory that nobody would have thought could have ever been agreed to. And I think it'll be bipartisan, in the sense that people are going to like a lot of the things that are in there. And probably some people won't; we're going to have that. And we'll probably do it maybe a little bit after our convention. We'll sign it after the convention.

Likewise, we're going to be doing a healthcare bill -- act -- and it'll be extremely comprehensive. It will cover a lot of things that nobody thought you would be able to get, and -- I mean, in a positive way. And I think it'll be very popular. And it will be a great thing for our country.

In addition, we have many other things. But immigration and healthcare -- it doesn't get much bigger than that. Immigration will be very merit-based, but it'll be -- it'll be great for the worker, and it'll be great for people coming into our country -- but coming into our country legally and loving our country and wanting to help our country, as opposed to people coming in and they don't like our country.

You see that, and you see that with certain of our politicians that ran for office. I say, "I don't think they like our country too much. All they do is complain." And you would never tell them to go back to their own country because that would be inappropriate, wouldn't it? But all they do is complain about our country, and their country is going to hell. So, you know, it's sort of an interesting phenomenon.

So the -- the merit-based immigration is going to be incredible, and the healthcare bill or act is going to be something that I don't think anybody in this country thought they'd ever see. And we've done much of that. If look at some of the legislation that we passed, Ken, I think you can say very strongly we've -- we've gotten things passed that nobody would be possible.

CUCCINELLI: That's right.

TRUMP: Whether it's Right to Try -- that's where you're terminally ill and you don't have a right to use our great medicines because they haven't been approved -- they're in a line of approval and it takes some time. We've cut the time in half, by the way, for approval by the FDA. But people are sick.

We have very promising drugs and they're not allowed to use them because -- I mean, they're terminally ill and they wouldn't let them use them because of liability and other things, but I got that taken care of. So, Right to Try was a very important one.

Getting Veterans Choice was so important -- having Veterans Choice. Nobody thought we could get that. Hasn't been done in 50 years. They haven't been able to get it. We got Veterans Choice. We got Veterans Accountability. Because we have so many other things. So many things.

And on the border, Ken, we've done things that nobody thought would have been possible. Right? Do you want to name a couple of them?

CUCCINELLI: We're making enormous progress in the -- especially in the regulatory arena: reestablishing the 140-year-old American tradition of inviting immigrants here who can stand on their own two feet, as -- much like Sara had said. And to add to this country and not -- while not becoming a burden on the country.

We've also -- the security that you've advocated for and pushed us to achieve has been unprecedented on a border that we still have more work to do. But we --

TRUMP: Great progress.

CUCCINELLI: -- the amount of improvement in three years is just extraordinary.

And one more piece of legislation you know is near and dear to my heart that you led is criminal justice reform, which was -- you know, lots of people before you talked about it, and this is the first administration to do it.

TRUMP: Nobody else could've gotten that done. Nobody. And we really thank Ken, but we thank a lot of people that came through.

By the way, some conservative -- very conservative really wanted it and some liberal wanted it. But we got criminal justice reform done. Nobody thought that was possible. The biggest beneficiary is African Americans and Hispanic Americans, I would say -- and Asian Americans -- the three, the groups.

But tremendous benefits and -- you know, it's really amazing. When we got that done, we had people supporting that that I would've never thought would've supported it. Not for bad reasons, but they would've never supported it, and they actually led the way. It's pretty incredible. Criminal justice reform was a big deal. You know that, Tim.

BURCHETT: Yes, sir.

TRUMP: So -- and you were helpful actually, and I appreciate it. And thank you very much. Anybody have a question?

QUESTION: Yes, Mr. President --

TRUMP: Go ahead.

QUESTION: Mr. President, on TikTok: You said over the weekend --

TRUMP: Yeah.

QUESTION: -- that you're planning to ban it. I know that you spoke with the CEO of Microsoft after that.

TRUMP: I did.

QUESTION: So can you give us an update on --

TRUMP: Yeah.

QUESTION: -- where you're at?

TRUMP: Yeah. We had a great conversation. He called me to see whether or not -- how I felt about it. And I said, "Look, it can't be controlled, for security reasons, by China. Too big, too invasive, and it can't be." And here is the deal: I don't mind if -- whether it's Microsoft or somebody else -- a big company, a secure company, very -- a very American company buy it. It's probably easier to buy the whole thing than to buy 30 percent of it. Because they say, "How do you do 30 percent? Who's going to get the name?" The name is hot; the brand is hot. And who's going to get the name? How do you do that if it's owned by two different companies?

So my personal opinion was: You're probably better off buying the whole thing rather than buying 30 percent of it. I think buying 30 percent is complicated. And I suggested that he can go ahead. He can try. We set a date -- I set a date at around September 15th, at which point it's going to be out of business in the United States. But if somebody -- and whether it's Microsoft or somebody else -- buys it, that'll be interesting.

I did say that if you buy it, whatever the price is, that goes to whoever owns it. Because I guess it's China, essentially, but more than anything else. I said a very substantial portion of that price is going to have to come into the Treasury of the United States because we're making it possible for this deal to happen. Right now, they don't have any rights, unless we give it to them. So if we're going to give them the rights, then it has to come into -- it has to come into this country.

It's a little bit like the landlord/tenant: Without a lease, the tenant has nothing. So they pay what's called "key money," or they pay something. But the United States should be reimbursed or should be paid a substantial amount of money, because without the United States, they don't have anything -- at least having to do with the 30 percent.

So I told him that. I think we're going to have -- maybe a deal is going to be made. It's a great asset. It's a great asset. But it's not a great asset in the United States unless they have the approval of the United States. So it'll close down on September 15th, unless Microsoft or somebody else is able to buy it and work out a deal -- an appropriate deal. So the Treasury of the -- really, the Treasury, I guess you would say, of the United States gets a lot of money. A lot of money. Okay?

QUESTION: Mr. President, can you explain why so many of the public health experts on the coronavirus task force are contradicting you on things like why the virus is so widespread in this country, on the efficacy of hydroxychloroquine? Why are so many of these people on your task force contradicting you?

TRUMP: Well, I think we're doing a great job. I think we're doing great on vaccines. We're doing great on therapeutics. You'll be seeing that very soon. I think we're -- when you look at a map, this is a map of the -- I've got -- I sort of shown that around a little bit, but that's -- the red is the area of most concern. (DISPLAYS A U.S. MAP.) Pretty recent map of the -- of the country. And there's a lot of -- a lot of people that -- in a lot of areas that have gotten very -- you know, better very fast.

Hydroxy has tremendous support, but politically, it's toxic because I supported it. If they would have said, "Do not use hydroxychloroquine under any circumstances," they would have come out and they would've said, "It's a great -- it's a great thing." Many doctors have come out strongly in favor of it. They want it very badly. It's a great malaria drug.

So, for many years --

QUESTION: But Admiral Giroir says it's not effective.

TRUMP: Let me finish my -- let me finish my answer.

So for many years -- it's, I guess, 60 years it's been a malaria drug; very successful, as you know. And it's been also a drug for lupus. And it caused no trouble -- virtually nothing, in terms of causing people to get sick or having problems with anything. You add the zinc and you add the azithromycin -- the Z-Pak, as they call it -- and it's been very -- I happened to take it myself, the threesome.

I took it myself for a period of two weeks. I mean, I -- I had no problem. I had no problem whatsoever. And, importantly, I, you know, didn't test positive. That's very nice. Okay? I'm very happy about that negative.

And so -- so that's the story. It's -- it's very highly thought of. Interestingly, a great doctor, from what I understand -- a great doctor from Yale feels very strongly about hydroxychloroquine. The Ford Clinic in Michigan came out with a very, very powerful paper saying it's very good. Many other -- in France, as you know, they came out with a very positive statement. Many individual doctors have come out with very positive statements.

I will tell you that if I was surrounded by people, as I was at the time -- the reason I took it: You know, we had some people that were relatively near me that tested positive. And I took it for that reason, just because I've heard good things.

QUESTION: But Fauci says it doesn't work. Admiral Giroir says it doesn't work.

TRUMP: I don't agree with Fauci on everything.

QUESTION: They're on your task force.

TRUMP: I don't agree with Fauci. Look, Fauci didn't want -- and I -- I like him. I get along with him actually great. But he didn't want to ban people from China from coming into the country, and I overrode him and I did the right thing. He was saying face masks are no good a short while ago. So it doesn't mean he's a bad person, because he's not. He's a good person; I like him. But we -- we disagree on things. We disagree on things.

Now, I will say this: We've done an amazing job with ventilators. We're supplying the world with ventilators. Ventilators are very hard, very expensive, very hard to make, very complex. Very complicated machines. Very -- very expensive.

QUESTION: But why does the --

TRUMP: Hold it. Hold it.

QUESTION: But why does the U.S. have so many deaths?

TRUMP: Hold it.

QUESTION: The U.S. has so many deaths compared to --

TRUMP: Hold it.

QUESTION: -- so many countries around the world. I --

TRUMP: Fake news CNN, hold it. We have done a great job in this country. We haven't been given -- and not me. I'm not talking about me. The Vice President, the task force have not been given the kind of credit.

If you look, countries all over the world are exploding right now -- people that you said were doing a wonderful job, so wonderful. But right now, take a look at the countries that are exploding: You have Italy back. You have Spain back. You have France back. You have Germany back. You have a lot of countries, and that's not to knock them.

It is a very delicate, very contagious disease. It was released by China. It should never have been allowed to release. There was the source where you could have stopped it. And they did stop it from going into China, although now they say that China is having a lot of problems. Moscow, in Russia, is having tremendous problems.

What China unleashed was a very, very sad situation. With all of that being understood, the United States has done an amazing job, a great job, and you're going to see that because we have vaccines and we have therapeutics coming very soon.

Yeah, go ahead.

QUESTION: Mr. President, why are you not involved directly in negotiations with Capitol Hill?

TRUMP: I am. Oh, why? The fact that I'm not over there with Crazy Nancy? No, I'm totally involved.

QUESTION: Have you spoken with her?

TRUMP: I'm totally involved. And we're going to be doing some things that are very good, because we don't think that she -- look, what Chuck Schumer wants more than anybody -- and I would say Nancy Pelosi would be second -- they want to bail out cities and states that have done a bad job over a long period of time. Nothing to do with coronavirus or China virus, or whatever you want to call it.

They want to bail out cities and states. They want bailout money. They want to trillion dollars in bailout money, and a lot of people don't want to do that because we don't think it's right. The Democrats have run some very bad states and some very, very bad cities, and a lot of people don't want to give them a trillion dollars to reward them for doing a bad job.

If you look at some of the states -- I won't insult anybody by naming those states, but you know what they are. They want bailout money. They're not interested in the people. They're not interested in unemployment. They're not interested in evictions, which is a big deal -- the evictions. They want to evict. A lot of people are going to be evicted, but I'm going to stop it because I'll do it myself if I have to. I have a lot of powers with respect to executive orders, and we're looking at that very seriously right now.

But what the Democrats want, they want -- they're slow-rolling it, and all they're really interested in is bailout money to bail out radical-left governors and radical-left mayors, like in Portland and places that are so badly run. Chicago, New York City -- you see what's going on over there. Bailout cities and states who have been poorly run and spent a fortune doing it, they want a trillion dollars, and we're really not interested in that.

Okay, thank you very much, everybody. Thank you. Thank you very much.

QUESTION: What about the Postal Service, Mr. President? What about the Postal Service? Any message to your postmaster general?

TRUMP: Thank you, Jim, very much. Thank you.

President Donald Trump Holds Media Availability With Tech Workers

August 03, 2020 11:30 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP (R-FLA.)

U.S. TECH WORKERS, PENNSYLVANIA FOUNDER KEVIN LYNN

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY, GEORGIA SERVICE MANAGEMENT IT OPERATIONS ENGINEER STACY WHETZELL

ENGINEERING ASSOCIATION, TENNESSEE PRESIDENT GAY HENSON

REP. TIM BURCHETT (R-TENN.) TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY RELIABILITY AND PERFORMANCE IT OPERATIONS ENGINEER DAVID LITTLEJOHN

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY, TENNESSEE ENTERPRISE RESOURCE PLANNING SOFTWARE ENGINEER WENDY TURNER

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY, TENNESSEE DISASTER RECOVERY ADMINISTRATOR CHUCK CHARNAWSKAS

SECRETARY OF LABOR EUGENE SCALIA

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY, ALABAMA IT END USER ANALYST LINDA MCDONALD

TENNESSEE ENGINEERING ASSOCIATION SPECIALIST RENAE MCKENZIE

DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY ACTING DEPUTY SECRETARY KEN CUCCINELLI

PROTECT US WORKERS, FLORIDA PRESIDENT SARA BLACKWELL

VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE (R-IND.)

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY SOFTWARE ENGINEER JONATHAN HICKS

[*]TRUMP: That's amazing.

Hello everybody. How are you?

UNKNOWN: Yes, sir. You do whatever you need.

BURCHETT: Don't call me, sir.

TRUMP: That's very nice. Do you feel comfortable with all those cameras on your head, congressman?

(LAUGHTER)

How are you?

Hello everybody.

Are we all set?

Well, thank you very much. And today I'm signing an Executive order to ensure that the federal government lives by a very simple rule: hire American. We've been doing it at a level that hasn't been done, maybe ever.

I'll also be taking firm disciplinary action against the leadership of the Tennessee Valley Authority, which has sadly, and truly betrayed American workers. And we have some of this great American workers with us at the table. This is the Cabinet Room. And it's an honor to have you in the Cabinet Room and being at the Oval Office.

We're joined by the vice president, Congressman Tim Burchett who's doing a fantastic job in the state of Tennessee, Secretary of Labor Eugene Scalia, acting deputy secretary of Homeland Security Ken Cuccinelli.

Where's Ken? Hi, Ken. I didn't see you down there. That's great. You're doing a great job.

CUCCINELLI: I'm quiet, as usual.

TRUMP: They're keeping you busy, right?

(LAUGHTER)

We're keeping you busy, Ken.

Recently, the CEO of the Tennessee Valley Authority, Jeffrey Lyash, made a disastrous and heartless decision. The TVA announced that it would layoff over two hundred American workers and replace them with cheaper foreign workers brought in from overseas. The Tennessee Valley Authority leadership then ordered the American workers to train their foreign replacements, rubbing salt in their very open wounds.

So we're going to bring in workers. They're going to be foreign workers and people from Tennessee and some other states right around it, are going to train them what to do and how to do it. It doesn't work that way.

As we speak, we're finalizing H-1B regulations so that no American workers is replaced ever again. H-1B should be used for top highly paid talent to create American jobs, not as inexpensive labor programs to destroy American jobs.

Sitting at the table are six of the TVA workers who were ordered to train the foreign labor flown in to replace them. I want you and your colleagues to know that my administration will not be putting up with it. I happen to know a young woman who's been very active over the last couple of years because we were together on Disney and a couple of other things.

BLACKWELL: (OFF-MIC) Yes, sir.

TRUMP: And it's all seems to be working out pretty well. You're doing a great job.

BLACKWELL: (OFF-MIC) Thank you.

TRUMP: And I thank you for it.

But that's why I'm formally removing the chairman of the board, James Thompson, and board member Richard Howorth. If the TVA does not move swiftly to reverse their decision to rehire their workers, then more board members will be removed.

We have the absolute right to remove board members, and the board makes the decision. I don't make the decision. I saw there was an ad on television talking about the amount of money that the chairman makes, and it's a ridiculous amount of money. But we have the right to--replace the board. And the board is the one, the only ones that get the right to then hire a new person.

urn:contentItem:60CG-8FM1-JB20-G167-00000-00President Donald Trump Recently Promised A Crackdown On Violence In American Cities, And This Comes As He's Picked Up The Endorsement Of A Top Police Organization; President Trump Held An Event At The White House After Making Some Changes In His Re-Election Campaign Staff, And Brad Parscale Is Out As Campaign Manager; We're All On The Same Team, Trump Pushes Back On Alleged Fauci-White House Feud; Twitter Hack, Profiles Of Prominent Figures Hijacked In Major Breach2020-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:18ZLexisNexisTHE FIVE5:00 PM ESTNEWSDomestic071601cb.258President Donald Trump Recently Promised A Crackdown On Violence In American Cities, And This Comes As He's Picked Up The Endorsement Of A Top Police Organization; President Trump Held An Event At The White House After Making Some Changes In His Re-Election Campaign Staff, And Brad Parscale Is Out As Campaign Manager; We're All On The Same Team, Trump Pushes Back On Alleged Fauci-White House Feud; Twitter Hack, Profiles Of Prominent Figures Hijacked In Major BreachDana Perino, Jesse Watters, Juan Williams, Dan Bongino, Emily Compagno

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Is that fair or right, or, simply because he worked for Donald Trump, not so fair, not so balanced? Tomorrow.

Here's "The Five."

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: Hello, everyone. I'm Juan Williams, along with Dana Perino, Jesse Watters, Dan Bongino, and Emily Compagno. It is 5:00 in New York City, and this is THE FIVE. President Trump promising a big crackdown on violence in cities, it comes as he's also picking up the endorsement of a top police organization.

The group had previously supported President Obama and Joe Biden. All that happening while the person seen here attacking New York City police has been arrested. The New York police department's top uniformed officer among the four injured. Here's what he just told Neil Cavuto.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There is a lot of animosity towards the police. And we are stealing (ph) -- not just in the protests when these anarchists take over but on the streets, on the street corners there is a feeling that they don't have to listen to the police and that they are willing to fight the police officers. We need our elected throughout the entire city to stand up and say that they support our police.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: And the head of the Department of Homeland Security now accusing politicians in Portland, Oregon, of enabling quote, "violent anarchists." Federal agents in that city using teargas to break up protesters trying to set a CHOP-like autonomous zone. Jesse, let me begin with you. This is obviously part of the president's strategy.

The National Association of Police Organizations announced their endorsement of President Trump on Shannon Bream's show last night. And the president recently said the police are not being treated fairly in this country. But I note that two-thirds of Americans say police violence against the public is a serious problem. So is the president out of sync with the public on this issue?

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST: No. I think the media is out of sync. I think the public, when you ask them, what is bigger problem, homicides or police maybe being too aggressive once in a while. I think they'd go with homicides, Juan. Now, I think everybody around this table agrees that I'm the most objective person here, so what I want to do is I want to look -- what's so funny?

I want to look at these anti-police movement objectively, all right? So it's been a month and a half since George Floyd tragically died. What are the tangible results of the movement? Let's judge the results here, specifically. Homicides are up everywhere. Hundreds of people have been injured, police officers included. Billions of dollars in property, people are fleeing cities.

They're buying weapons, COVID-19 was spread, cancel culture got out of control. There have been at least 20 people killed in the riots as a result of this, so what were the accomplishments, because Democrats blocked police reform. What, a statue is toppled? The Redskins change their name. Someone resigned from the New York Times, really?

Is that what the BLM movement gave birth to? Is that really it? Because at this point, you have to say to yourself is this movement objectively -- has it been a bust? Because I don't think this move in opinion if -- you can't quantify that at a poll because I don't even believe some of the polls about what people think about police or the black lives matter movement.

I'm talking about action. And the action has been tragic. There has been a move towards anarchy and fear and violence, not towards unity and peace as a result of this. So all the people that stoked these fires, the elite people in the media or the elected politicians, they need to look themselves in the mirror and say, am I proud of what this has accomplished?

Am I satisfied with the result of this movement? Because I think it's just -- people are now picking up the pieces as a result of this. And what's another four years later in the next election? We're going to do this all over again. People are hurting. So I don't see this as a positive movement at this point. I think people are hurt and scared now.

WILLIAMS: OK, all right. So Dana, let's pick up on what Jesse is talking about, because the president said in an interview this week with CBS that more white people are killed by police than black people. And I think that's true in absolute numbers. But of course, blacks are a smaller percentage of the population and his critics are pointing out that blacks are a small percentage of the population.

And his critics are pointing out that blacks are more likely to be shot and killed by police than whites. So why is the president not showing any sensitivity to that side of the argument?

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: You know, he has done a lot of interviews this week where he has been asked things that were not having to do with Coronavirus or the economic condition of the country. And on this one, I think part of it is just knowing to how to read the room a little bit, the room being the country. And it's not that he was factually inaccurate.

But there is room here for empathy and he has shown that. And at the same time, he is looking at his home city of New York, going through horrific violence, the police officers feeling completely demoralized. You had the actual police chief be injured in this. You had crime spiking way up, and then you have the fact that you de-funded a billion dollars from that police department, disbanded the anti-crime unit.

And they put forward a piece of legislation that maybe Dan can explain a little bit more. But it basically says that the police officers are not allowed to touch a suspect, if they are under arrest, anywhere on the torso, which basically means you are not able to arrest. So the crime will continue to go up. I think those are the two things actually that could maybe be turned around pretty quickly if the NYPD was willing to do that.

And I also feel like when you talk about law and order, people are concerned about that. It is not something that you can just deal with in New York City, when you see it in Portland, when you see it in Washington, Los Angeles. I mean, it is nationwide that every single city is dealing with this everywhere. But we know how this works.

This starts to pop up in other cities, it migrates other places. It took years to get us to the place where we had a very safe city in New York. And it takes a just a couple of weeks to destroy that unless somebody does something pretty quickly.

WILLIAMS: Yes. So Dan, picking up on the question Dana was asking you, we have seen an increase in gun sales now after the marches that followed George Floyd's death. And of course, people are saying some of this is a result of racial anxiety, you know, fear that there's going to be more racial unrest or may be racial violence. So is racial concern behind the spike in gun purchases?

DAN BONGINO, FOX NEWS HOST: No. No one is saying that, Juan, only, you know, the liberal nuts are saying that. People are buying guns because they don't feel safe. Adding some racial connotation to it that nobody has any evidence of whatsoever is just liberal nut bags. That's not a real thing people are saying just to be clear. And it's kind of rational.

I mean, wouldn't you say? I mean, if you are watching your community being burned to the ground, your store being burned to the ground, people attacking innocent, hit them with canes and riot while the police are hamstrung and not able to respond. What would you do? I mean, it would be irrational to not want to defend yourself, right?

I mean, I'm not crazy, right? And secondly, I think President Trump, that's how the segment started that he's -- the crackdown is coming. He's kind of done asking at this point. He doesn't need the mayor's authority in Chicago and New York to go in and enact -- and enforce federal crimes. He doesn't need them at all. He's tried to work with them.

He's tried to play nice. They are not interested. They are interested in chaos and promoting chaos. He can send in the FBI, Secret Service, DEA, IRS, ATF, you name it for a task force tomorrow and enforce federal crimes. He doesn't need their permission. And I think he's done asking and I applaud that. One more point, I've heard a lot of commentary by liberals on cable news and in radio.

The first step here is acknowledging a problem. And if I hear one more person try to say there isn't a crime wave or this is some kind of figment of our imagination, or it's just due to the hot summer, I'm going to lose my mind. That is absolutely not true. It is the tangible result of pulling anti-crime officers off the street, bail reform, and losing broken policing in favor of bail reform. I mean, the evidence is everywhere and ignoring it just makes anyone promoting that propaganda looks silly. I'm very sorry.

WILLIAMS: Well, I disagree with you but we will talk about that later. Let me get to Emily. Emily, Representative Ilhan Omar was in the Washington Post with an op-ed column today. She says President Trump is being unfair to her when he says that she wants to dismantle America because she says the protests need to go beyond the police and call for better schools, housing, healthcare, and jobs. Do you think she has a point, Emily?

EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS HOST: I don't, because she wasn't calling for that in that specific way. And she 100 percent stands for the destruction of America. But I want to focus on something else for a moment. I want to echo Jesse and Dan's point as well as the NYPD chiefs points, which is that the violence and the destruction has been totally emboldened by the ineffectiveness of these local leaders.

I wanted to show support for Seattle's law enforcement. So last night, I teamed with a local restaurant and we delivered dinner to the North Precinct. And seeing their -- hearing their stories and their concerns and witnessing their low morale was so distressing. Our small gesture had the biggest impact on them because these guys are flying solo.

And they're also mourning the loss of an officer that was shot and killed to death, Jonathan Shoop, on Monday night. And they are questioning whether their community supports them because we know the mayor doesn't. And the common thread all night in the conversations that we had with them was that this time is so different. These are veterans, you guys. These are not rookies.

They have seen it all. And yet, they have never seen this level of violence and vitriol and racism, by the way. A ton of stories I could never say on air, from these so-called protesters. And the fact that as we talking about the effectiveness of local leaders, the fact that for example Mayor Durkin here only when protesters got to her house, through her gate.

Did she call it rioters' actions and incitement? But she let the CHOP zone destroy that city for weeks. And one of the officers made a great point to me. She said, you know, it came to her house, and so she stopped the protests then. But what about our house, that east precinct was my home, and I had to abandon it. And the fact that these guys have to question who supports them and why is heartbreaking to me.

WILLIAMS: That's a good story, Emily. Coming up next, it's a midsummer shake-up, President Trump dropping his campaign manager, what that means for the 2020 campaign, straight ahead for you on THE FIVE.

PERINO: President Trump holding an event at the White House after shaking up his re-election campaign staff. Brad Parscale, he is out as campaign manager with polls showing that Vice President Biden is ahead of him in many of the polls. And taking over the big job is veteran GOP operative, Bill Stepien. Parscale will stay on as a senior adviser, meantime, the president attacking Joe Biden today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Our entire economy and our very way of life are threatened by Biden's plans to transform our nation and subjugate our communities through the blunt force instrument of federal regulation at a level that you haven't even seen yet. You think that was bad? You haven't even seen it yet. They want to go many times what they put you under in the past.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PERINO: All right. So that's at the White House just a few minutes ago. Jesse, the campaign needed a shot in the arm. Is this campaign personnel change going to help that problem?

WATTERS: I think it will. Let's remember, Donald Trump fired two campaign managers in 2016 in he still smoked Crooked Hillary. I don't know. I think Parscale did a great job building an online army. They're raising more money from small donors than Joe Biden. They have better situational awareness, the battleground states than Joe Biden does.

They had better data. And they are just more in touch with their base than Joe Biden is. So Brad's going to pass the torch to Bill and Bill is more of a national strategist, more of a national campaign manager. But let's be honest, President Trump is his own strategist and probably has got pretty good instincts. He's one and 0 when he's running for president.

Joe Biden, not that great, that's why Joe Biden has to rely more on his campaign manager, that campaign manager is going to making all the decisions for Joe. And let's remember, Joe Biden also got rid of his campaign manager just a few months ago. So that's not that big of a deal. If the president just stays focused on the economy, China, and getting this vaccine before November, I think he wins.

PERINO: Don't forget cancel culture because that is still a big issue. I do want to read you a little bit of a statement from Bill Stepien, so he is the new campaign manager. And he said something I thought was pretty interesting, Dan. He basically is saying that with 109 days left, our goal is clear. To win each day, we have left until Election Day.

If we win more days then Joe Biden wins, President Trump will be re- elected. And I want to talk to you about just how quickly this time could go between now and Election Day. Weeks go by very, very fast. And you have to try to win every single news cycle, every single day. And it's been a while since they could claim over a week's time.

So the other point is Bill Stepien has a record of winning races that are against the odds. Republicans Governor, Chris Christie was re-elected by 22-point state margin -- margin in a state as blue as New Jersey.

BONGINO: Yes, a couple of things on this about winning the media cycle, that's tough. I mean, listen. The media overwhelmingly, 95 percent of it, no matter what Trump does it's going to paint him as anti-Trump story. It doesn't -- we've heard all the analogy (ph). We've heard all that. It's true. I mean, it's sadly true. They'd be on the side like a deadly disease if they can beat up Trump in a message.

It's pathetic. But having said that, you know, I think the palace intrigue angle for this is being overplayed, because some, again, not all, but some in the media want to play up the Trump team chaos. You know, we've heard it all before. I don't think this is a particularly big deal. Brad's not going anywhere. His expertise is digital. He does a fantastic job.

That's what he's doing. So putting that aside, I think the move more to where it's clearing up the message is a good one. You know, the president said it once in a press conference, Dana. It's one -- I don't get goose bumps anymore. I don't -- you know, I ran for office. I'm not particularly impressed by politicians.

But he gave a speech one. And he said it, you know, we will build it again, talking about the economy. And I got to tell you, I got goose bumps. Because I thought, yes, that's it, like, that's the message. We say that we, us, all of us, collectively saved ourselves from the dreadful Obama economy, this disaster that was handed to us. And we are all better off because of it before this plague hit us.

It was a great message. And if we can mail that, we will build that again, that optimistic message, I think he'll be in pretty good shape.

PERINO: And Emily, you've talked about small businesses before and the regulations and how it was hamstringing small businesses, the president doing a -- putting a focus on that today at the White House, saying that, you know, the deregulation push that they have done in the Trump administration is at risk if Biden were to win. Get your thoughts on that type of an economic message from the White House.

COMPAGNO: That's exactly right, Dana. I also think it's specifically important for him to weigh in on COVID policies and regulations, that in this critical period of small businesses and all businesses to get back on their feet, it's important for leadership to set regulations that are business friendly. So going into 2016, for example, just regulations in general hamstring the average company all the time.

But now, it's even more crucial. So if he dovetails that message in with the -- as Dan pointed out, all of us getting back on our feet together, that's where the message will succeed.

PERINO: Juan, the Biden campaign's -- campaign director, Jen O'Malley Dillon, she put out a statement with some members that they have really upped their fundraising. They have a lot more cash on hand then they had before. Of course, she was additionally for more money. As I understand it, they sort of blew off the changes in the Trump campaign management structure. Is that something you've heard as well?

WILLIAMS: Yes. Look, the reality is that this late, you know, about three months out basically to the election, you don't fire your campaign manager if things are going well. And what we saw yesterday in the polling was, you know, NBC had Biden up by 11. Quinnipiac had him up by 15. That's a pretty big margin, Dana. So I think people are, you know, finally, you know, up inside the campaign, acknowledging what we all had been seeing as a reality.

I feel bad, I got to tell you, for Brad Parscale. He is a nice guy. And I don't think that it's really about Brad Parscale. Jesse said this. I think this is about the candidates. It's about Donald Trump. And Trump is of running basically a rerun of 2016, division, name-calling, no vision, no answer, especially no answer in terms of Coronavirus.

And so he has bad numbers in terms of handling of the number one issue on the American mind. And I think that makes this election a referendum on him and he's not doing well.

PERINO: We'll see. We're actually going to talk about Coronavirus little bit next, because Dr. Anthony Fauci is reacting after being accused of being wrong about everything by a top White House advisor. We will talk about that next.

WATTERS: President Trump pushing back on reports of a feud with Dr. Anthony Fauci. It comes after White House trade advisor, Peter Navarro, went after the task force member in an op-ed titled, Anthony Fauci has been wrong about everything. I have interacted with him on. Despite that, the president says he and Fauci have a good relationship.

But meanwhile, Fauci appearing on the digital cover of InStyle and saying he and Trump are on good terms, Fauci also defending his credibility.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES: I believe for the most part you can trust respected medical authorities. You know, I believe I am one of them. So I think you can trust me. But I would stick with respected medical authorities who have a track record of telling the truth.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: All right. Dan, Fauci looks very comfortable with his legs crossed by the pool, very jealous of that kind of relaxation, but I'm here on THE FIVE. I will say this. Listen, he's not an evil guy. He's a very smart individual, but he has been wrong. He downplayed the virus in the beginning. He was wrong about the travel ban and the masks and Hydroxychloroquine. Is it not OK to criticize someone at all?

BONGINO: No, no. Of course -- listen, they're public figures. I mean, anyone in the public is going to be criticized. I don't take a job as a public figure. I'm not sure the InStyle magazine cover was necessarily, you know, the best idea. Maybe a journal of the American Medical Association cover would have been a little bit more suited to the times.

But here's -- there it is right there. But here's the problem I see. And it's not personal. I'm not here to pile on Dr. Fauci. He certainly has far more medical expertise than I do. But Jesse, this is a multi-factorial problem here. There are a number of factors. It's not just the virus. And I think you have the old hammer-nail analogy.

When you are a hammer, everything looks like a nail. When you're an epidemiologist and a virologist, everything is seen through the lens of a problem of the virus. And that's good. And I'm glad we have that expertise. In the triaging of our needs, that's at the top. But that is not only concern. We can't, you know, have people just spouting off in, you know, in the White House saying, you know what, a lockdown maybe a good idea.

You're going to crash the stock market. That has a real effect on people. It's not a joke. You can't just recommend a lockdown haphazardly and say, well, you know, we can shutdown the virus. Yes, well, you could also shutdown the hospital treating the virus. Did you think any of this through?

WATTERS: Right.

BONGINO: Because you can't do elective procedures and they need to stay in business. What about our food supply that we strained (ph)? Did anyone think of that? That's a problem with placing too much faith in any one doctor or otherwise.

WATTERS: And Dana, obviously, presidents can listen to lots of advice from lots of people. They don't have to just tailor everything someone tells them and just follow everything willy-nilly. It's like, the president just doesn't listen to the Joint Chiefs of Staff and do everything they tell him to do. He gets a wide variety of opinions and then makes that decision.

PERINO: I think the attacks on Fauci have been one of the things that is just -- it is mind boggling. And I -- and here's the thing. Even Fauci himself said repeatedly, I'm just a guy that has one opinion, I am not the person who has to make the big decisions on all these different things. I'm just this guy.

This is somebody who has a credibility factor that is way far above what anybody else is having on this conversation, whether you like it or not. So then you have people like, oh, well, he was wrong on all of these things, and they keep repeating it, and then the President has to this week, constantly like backtrack, like oh, actually, no, I have a good relationship. No, actually, I'm going to call him. No, actually, Peter Navarro is wrong.

And it's -- if you are looking as a young person You want to understand how do you develop gravitas? Dr. Fauci is somebody you could look to because he is accomplished, he is credible, he's also having fun, and he's willing to push back and defend himself, but in a way that has protected his relationship with the president. That is skillful. And I think that we should all be grateful that this person is still willing to help all of us think these things through from his -- from his perspective.

And he again says he doesn't have all the answers. He's not the decision- maker. All he is, is informing the president. And I was glad the president called him yesterday because that -- keeping that relationship is really important for all of us in the future.

WATTERS: Yes, I mean, I definitely would agree that beefing with Fauci is not the greatest strategy right now. Juan Williams, I mean, Fauci came on "WATTERS WORLD" and he said, listen, I got things wrong. If I had to go back in time, I do things differently. But where's Birx? I love Deborah Birx. Where's she been, I wonder?

WILLIAMS: I think she's a little more inside right now than even Dr. Fauci. Look, I mean, you know, the President had his social media people mocking Fauci, then you see the column criticizing Fauci, and guess what, you know what, Fauci is not allowed on T.V. very much anymore, that's why he's doing things like InStyle, right. I mean, he's much more online and you can pick up, and the T.V. stations pick that up.

But the point here is that the president, President Trump is the president. He's the decider. And if he wanted to fire Fauci, just get him out of here, he could do it. But he doesn't want to do that because Fauci is very popular with the American people. The American people do trust Dr. Fauci and think that he is credible and speaks directly to them with good information about this virus.

I mean, the big issue the last two days has been that the White House wanted all the hospitals to funnel information about the virus to them, through the Department of Health and Human Services, not to the CDC. They had to reverse that today and say no, no, we understand the criticism is so intense that we're going to politicize the data. It'll continue going to CDC.

But again, that's an illustration of how dangerous it is to play politics with the American people's health. We're worried about this virus.

WATTERS: Yes, I don't think they're playing politics with it. I just think it's a different way of doing business. OK, let's finish it up. What do you think?

COMPAGNO: I think that this isn't like a football game where we get excited about the competition, and we're all like, oh, oh. This is our livelihoods and our lives. So, I 100 percent support the president right now in getting that messaging out that yes, we are all on the same team.

And Dr. Fauci in that InStyle article. He said, it's pretty tough to try to get out your messaging and walk a tightrope, and everything you say is being pitted against the president. He said, it's very stressful. So I think ultimately we should all look at this, as Dana said, that we are all Americans, we're all learning as we go to an extent.

And you're right Jesse, we should always be able to criticize those in power. But when it's our health and our livelihoods that is at stake, I think it's most important for us to all be on the same team.

WATTERS: Agreed. And wear a mask. It can't hurt.

PERINO: And a tie.

WATTERS: Coming up, Twitter suffers a massive hack. A new report say it could have been an inside job. All the details ahead.

BONGINO: Hackers taking over several high-profile Twitter accounts in on of social media is most brazen cyberattacks yet. The FBI is now investigating after Joe Biden, Jeff Bezos, Apple, and many more posted bizarre messages that promoted a cryptocurrency scam. Reports indicate it was an inside job with hackers reportedly paying a Twitter employee who helped them gain access to the accounts. Experts say it could have been worse.

Emily, before I go to you, just a disclosure, I am one of the owners of a competitor to Twitter, Parler. So, I just want to put that out there. But are they in trouble here, Twitter? I mean, with your legal expertise, are they in some kind of legal trouble for this, you think?

PERINO: Sure.

COMPAGNO: They might be. There's always legal exposure. But I will say that this to me, is just an illustration that nothing is impenetrable. And this was a pretty minor example, frankly, but it just goes to show that yes, hacking can absolutely bring down planes and power grids and people and it is frightening.

And I think moving forward, it's important for people too to understand the death by drips that's happening just by using these devices, all of our data is being utilized and sold. And to me, there's no such thing as privacy or security. It's not a question of if it's just a question of when.

BONGINO: Juan, I mean, this was pretty serious. Can you imagine if they hacked into your account and said like, I'm voting Trump in 2020 or something like that? Can you imagine your audience would be like, what happened?

COMPAGNO: We'd know it was hacked.

BONGINO: Yes. Which is why the FBI is on the page.

WILLIAMS: You know, but I got to -- I got to say, I think this is serious. I know, we're laughing, but I think this is a really serious event that's worthy of FBI and Congressional investigation, because picking up on what Emily said about, you know, taking down airplanes or the grid, how about the stock market? How about an election?

You know, you could start a war. Getting the President's account, you could start a war for us and, you know, global catastrophe. So to me, this is the latest example of how social media, but big tech in general, is really begging for regulation, begging for someone to get involved and say, here are the rules of the road because right now greed and competence whatever, they seem to be running blind and they're running over us.

BONGINO: Well, I think the greediest people following government, that's what always worries me as Friedman always said. But Jesse, you know, Juan is not wrong. I mean, this was -- this one is serious. I mean, they could have posted to President Trump's account you know, some devastating national security message and cause the real situation.

WATTERS: Juan is not wrong, Dan?

BONGINO: Listen --

WATTERS: Even when he's right, you can't admit that. You never admit that. It's going to get him all cocky.

BONGINO: Yes, yes.

WATTERS: No, I mean, in my opinion, this was the dumbest hack of all time. I mean, just to get some Bitcoin money? I mean, if you really wanted to make money, you say something that tanks stocks and then place a short bet and clean up. So I don't really get what was going on here. These guys obviously need to hire better I.T. people. Maybe not the guys from the DNC, but I'm sure there's some I.T. people that could make something impenetrable, as Emily said.

They should probably start worrying about banning hackers instead of conservatives. Their priorities are all sorts of messed up. When this thing happened, I thought to myself, you know, only the important people are being hacked. So, I almost wanted to tweet the exact same thing about Bitcoin just to make myself seem important, like I got hacked.

And then I thought maybe Fox might not like that, so I didn't do it. But at this point, I only look at Twitter twice a day. When I wake up in the morning to see the news, and then right at 6:00 to see if I've said anything offensive that's gone viral. Right now, Twitter is so tedious. I mean, it's like real housewives. Everyone's kind of jockeying for attention.

Your account is great Dan, or Dana, I love your account, Emily, everyone is accounts great on this show, but -- even Gutfeld.

BONGINO: Well, Dana, they locked out the blue checkmarks for a bit yesterday to clean up the problem. And America suffered Jasper withdrawals. There were no Jasper pictures for two hours. It's unthinkable.

WATTERS: You got to go to Instagram.

PERINO: That's right. I made up for it this morning because those pictures were just impossible not to put up there. And the thing about Juan is that even when he's right, he's still Juan.

WILLIAMS: Thank you.

PERINO: Here's one of my concerns. I -- well, first of all, the company is saying that they're -- that it wasn't somebody from the inside that gave access. We'll see. I think the investigation will turn up what it turns out fine. What I'm concerned about is that whoever it was, that this was a dry run for something much more serious. And so that's why I think the FBI has to be involved immediately. This is a public safety issue at this point.

BONGINO: Yes, that's interesting, fascinating. Coming up next, CNN attacks President Trump -- there we go -- after his latest defense of Goya. Stay tuned.

COMPAGNO: Welcome back. Liberal calls for a boycott of soy foods prompting President Trump and his daughter Ivanka to post on social media supporting the company. It has CNN very upset. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS CUOMO, ANCHOR, CNN: You tell me how a president in the middle of a pandemic has got time for this (BLEEP). Are you kidding me? Hawking products, Goya, I don't care who it is. Resolute desk, this is what he's resolute about.

ANDERSON COOPER, ANCHOR, CNN: We're in a public health battle for our lives and our futures and the President is sitting there behind the Resolute Desk, resolutely clutching at beans.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

COMPAGNO: Dan Bongino, why is it so impossible for the mainstream media to focus on the real issue?

BONGINO: Well, I mean, their mainstream media, they're just embarrassing buffoons. I mean, look at those two. I mean, Chris Cuomo, I'm super surprised he's not doing triceps curls at his desk. But these liberal boycotts are always an embarrassing failure. Remember the Chick-Fil-A boycott? You couldn't get a chicken sandwich for 47 square miles in my neighborhood after the alleged boycott. You can't find a black bean can anywhere in my local neighborhood after their so-called boycott.

But there's a reason, and the reason is the liberals who allegedly boycott these -- you know, sit in their basements and have no jobs and watch Teletubby videos all day, unemployed, roasting smores. So they have no buying power, while conservatives who have jobs will go out and support people who stand up for the United States. So these boycotts are always a hilarious busts and they're kind of fun to watch these idiots implode.

COMPAGNO: Dana, what are the larger consequences here?

PERINO: Well, it depends. I mean, it is possible, as Dan says that the Goya could become the new Chick-Fil-A and so cows everywhere will continue to be happy. But I do think that there's a possibility here that after the election, after this is no longer useful to anybody politically, that there are long term possible consequences for the company that has 4,000 employees, so there's that.

And then the other thing is I do think that this is a company that has done incredible charitable work for Latinos especially in the time of the pandemic, making sure that they were out there providing food, whatever else was needed in the Latino community like very, very much focused on that.

And when the liberals and these other liberal groups try to go after this company for expressing, you know, a First Amendment right with the president and being grateful for having been there, then I do think you have to look back and say, what have you done for the Latino community? How many -- how many Latinos are on your board? Because it's 100 percent Latinos on the Goya board.

So I think that if people try to make political hay out of it, they have to understand that there could be long term consequences. But those on the left trying to hurt Goya, they're actually just biting off their nose to spite their face.

COMPAGNO: Juan, I had the pleasure of interviewing the Goya of food CEO on "FOX & FRIENDS," and he shared with me that when Michelle Obama, then-First Lady, invited him to the White House to work with her, he accepted, and also he accepted the Trump administration's invitation to attend the White House. Why is respecting the office of the presidency such a deal-breaker for Democrats?

WILLIAMS: I don't think it's just Democrats. I think it's specifically Latinos and maybe most of all Mexican Americans who feel that the President has attacked immigrants from Mexico, you know, demean them, mock them, call them names. I think there's the reason.

But look, in this instance, you know, why is it that owning the libs and culture wars is more important than anything to the president? Why is it more important than dealing with the pandemic? I just don't get it. I think that putting those cans there, holding a can of beans like he's the king of the world, I mean, it seems to me misplaced priorities in the in this current pandemic.

COMPAGNO: Jesse, what are your thoughts?

WATTERS: Trump is defending Mexican food. Really, CNN has said about that? I thought CNN said he hates Mexicans, and now they're upset because he's defending Mexican food. Which one is it CNN? I mean -- and liberals are the ones boycotting Mexican food. It's like everything's up and you can't make sense of it.

COMPAGNO: That's true. All right, guys, stay with us, "ONE MORE THING" is up next.

WILLIAMS: It's time now for "ONE MORE THING." Jesse?

WATTERS: It's time for Jesse's fish tales. I caught something. All right, so there's this crazy fish out of Malaysia. Look at this sucker. This guy is called a trigger fish. And check out chompers. These guys usually (AUDIO GAP) it's very aggressive. of the males (AUDIO GAP). I don't know about you guys, but I am definitely triggered by this fish.

WILLIAMS: Wow, that was interesting. Dana?

PERINO: Look like he had a good dentist too. I'm going to talk to you about a little baby and a big dog. Check out Nicholas. He's one years old, and he has a family dog named Odin, 140-pound Newfoundland. And Nicholas' parents say that Odin thinks that this little guy is his baby. So he protects him and always make sure he's OK. And in fact, Nicholas, his first words were wolf, wolf, which is something I think -- I think Greg's first words were wolf, wolf, right before animals are great.

Also, new podcasts, I'll Tell You What, with Chris Stirewalt. We talked about all sorts of things like when I was -- when we had the podcast, I was having an -- I was over-caffeinated so don't listen at 1.5 speed. That's all I got to say.

BONGINO: I got that problem often.

COMPAGNO: Nice.

WILLIAMS: Wow, you're going fast. OK, you've heard of searching for pirate's treasure. Well, how about searching for a treasure hidden by a Michigan jeweler? Yes, take a look. That's Johnny Perry, a jeweler in Washington Township, Michigan. Mr. Perry buried $1 million, I repeat, $1 million worth of precious metal and gyms in the state. He hid it in waterfalls, streams, and even in the woods, and he put a GPS device on every treasure to keep track of it.

The first hunt begins August 1st, then people will be looking for two 100- ounce silver bars. The worth $40,200. Jesse, Dana, Dan, Emily, are you coming with me?

WATTERS: I'm right behind you, Juan.

COMPAGNO: Yes, that sounds awesome.

BONGINO: Yes.

PERINO: I'm right behind.

WILLIAMS: All right, Dan, you're up.

BONGINO: All right, so this Vancouver couple, they took the plunge into marriage and into the lake too. So Laura and Jordan decided they were going to take a photo doing a little dance move. And you see that, little dip on the dock. Yes, yes, it did not -- we all know where this is going. It's very dramatic picture, so dramatic they actually fell in the water.

Listen they all had good spirits about it. They emerged from the water, went back to the party, everybody is wondering why you all wet. Well, we fell in the water, brushed off some makeup, got right back to business. Good for them, classic photo, now you're all famous on THE FIVE, so good for you and good luck.

WATTERS: Best of luck.

WILLIAMS: Emily, you're up.

COMPAGNO: All right, guys, Remember the best show of all time The Golden Girls?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Oh your house is just breathtaking.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I know.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: You said it looks like a dump from the outside.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

COMPAGNO: All right, so you guys, that house is for sale. And even though the shows are placed in Miami, the house itself is in Brentwood in L.A. We can all pull our money and buy it for about $3 million. Juan, I will go on the treasure hunt with you if you go on this house with me. What do you say?

WATTERS: Wow, yes, that's a beautiful house. And everybody loves it because they remember Golden Girls.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back.

Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Tuesday, August 20th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast on the button.

We are watching retail this morning. Kohl's is set to report momentarily. We'll bring you those numbers as soon as they hit. We're expecting $1.53 on revenue of $4.2 billion.

This comes on top of Home Depot reported last hour. Home Department cut its full year sales guidance. It is citing lower lumber prices and potential tariffs -- potential tariffs. But saying that the current health of the U.S. consumer is strong and the stable housing environment continues to support the business at Home Depot. Shares are up now 1.25 percent.

Markets this morning are higher. Take a look at futures looking to extend the rally of yesterday, although the Dow Industrials just turned negative. Dow futures now down 5 points. S&P futures are unchanged right now. And the Nasdaq futures are up 2.75 points. There seems to be some selling coming on right here as we speak.

This after stocks kicked off the week with a big rally yesterday. Take a look. DowIndustrials were up 249 points. The S&P was up 35. And the Nasdaq was up 106, one and a third percent.

Kohl's numbers are coming out and they look like a beat on the earnings line. We want to look at global markets this morning and check Kohl's. Let's get to Ashley Webster right now with the breaking news on Kohl's -- Ashley.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes. Hello -- Maria.

Let's get earnings per share coming in on an adjusted basis of $1.55, beating the estimate by two cents. Revenue also beating, coming in at $4.43 billion. The estimate was for $4.2 billion. Although comp sales -- comparable sales are down 2.9 percent although the outlook which was for guidance of $5.15 to $5.45 on EPS, they are maintaining that guidance.

So no change to the outlook for the rest of the year. A beat on the top and the bottom, although as we just said, the comparable sales down 2.9 percent. And those are the headlines we have so far -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Stock is down 2.5 percent right now - -Ashley. We'll be watching that.

WEBSTER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much.

WEBSTER: Sure.

BARTIROMO: We want to look at this retail sector because obviously consumer spending is two-thirds of the economy.

Our top story this morning though, the Israel controversy. Representatives Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib condemning Israel's travel restrictions yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. ILHAN OMAR (D), MINNESOTA: The decision to ban me and my colleagues - - my colleague -- the first two Muslim American women elected to Congress, is nothing less than an attempt by an ally of the United States to suppress our ability to do our jobs as elected officials. Denying visits to duly- elected members of Congress is not consistent with being an ally.

REP. RASHIDA TLAIB (D), MICHIGAN: It is unfortunate that Prime Minister Netanyahu has apparently taken a page out of Trump's book and even this direction from Trump to deny this opportunity.

OMAR: We are going to fight this administration and the oppressive Netanyahu administration until we take our last breath.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Their comments following the White House's response to reports that Democrats may retaliate against Israel with legislative action against top American and Israeli diplomats.

The White House says this. "Congresswomen Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar have a well-documented history of anti-Semitic comments, anti-Semitic social media posts and anti-Semitic relationships. Israel has the right to prevent people who want to destroy it from entering the country. And Democrats' pointless congressional inquiries here in America cannot change the laws Israel has passed to protect itself."

Joining us right now is Tennessee Congressman, House Financial Services Committee member David Kustoff. Congressman -- good to see you. Thanks very much for being here this morning.

REP. DAVID KUSTOFF (R), TENNESSEE: Good morning -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: So you are one of only two Jewish Republicans in the House of Representatives. What's your reaction to all of this?

KUSTOFF: you know, my reaction is -- first of all, as we know, Israel passed a law within the last couple of years to ban people from traveling to Israel who may do harm to the country. But even going back, you know, within the past two weeks we saw Republican and Democrat freshmen members of Congress go on a -- they go every other year to Israel with their leaders, Steny Hoyer and Kevin McCarthy. It's a tradition.

Those two members could have gone with their freshmen class -- their freshmen members, both Republican and Democrat, to learn more about Israel, to learn more about the Palestinian Authority and how we interact in the world. They chose on their own not to go on that trip. And I think they wanted this trip obviously that they wanted to take to make a statement to further promote BDS, which we as a nation oppose.

BARTIROMO: Look, BDS is obviously Boycott Israel. And you think that was a complete, direct, you know, intentional decision not to go on the trip with Kevin McCarthy and Steny Hoyer and instead just try to make a lot of noise around their own trip.

KUSTOFF: Well, it was to make -- it was to make a statement. Because again, it's a tradition that all the freshmen Republicans and Democrats travel together to Israel. They could have gone on this trip. They chose not to go on the trip.

Well, Chick-fil-A tweeted, quote, bun plus chicken plus pickles, equals all the love for the original, end quote. Popeyes responded with a snide, you all good, OK. Then Wendy's decided they were going to jump in at this whole thing. You all out here fighting about which of these fools has the second best chicken sandwich. Not to be (INAUDIBLE) I'm trying to keep up.

Then Popeye's jumped in and they said, sounds like someone just ate one of our biscuits because you all looking thirsty. I just want to you alls in this.

We'll see who wins, Maria, the poultry war. I guess fried chicken and southerners just kind of go hand in hand. My grandmother made great fried chicken, so maybe that's true. There you are.

BARTIROMO: Great.

CASONE: Chicken war.

BARTIROMO: All right, best chicken sandwich. Do you have a fave?

CASONE: Chick-fil-A, memory serves.

BARTIROMO: I think that's yours too.

BEVAN: Chick-fil-A's on top, sure.

FERRIS: Aren't cardiologists winning this war?

BARTIROMO: Yes, there you go, cardiologist.

All right, quick break, thank you, Cheryl. We are at the height of the ice cream season meanwhile. My next guest company celebrates the summer treat with flavors made right here in the USA. We're taking a look and a taste, coming up.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Made in America, one of the oldest family run ice cream merchants in American history with us today. They turned a unique recipe into an international best seller.

Joining us right now is Bassetts Ice Cream vice president of distribution, Alex Bassett Strange. Great to have you, Alex. Thank you so much for joining us.

ALEX BASSETT STRANGE, VICE PRESIDENT OF DISTRIBUTION, BASSETTS ICE CREAM: Good morning. Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Wow, six generations. Tell us about the company.

STRANGE: Well, so we are America's oldest ice cream brand, we've been around since 1861. The company was started by my great, great, great grandfather. We are based in Philadelphia, we are in the Reading Terminal Market. In Philadelphia we have -- that's where our company owned retail store is. We've been making ice cream and serving it there in the Reading Terminal Market for 158 years.

BARTIROMO: Wow. And you've gone international, right? So you also sell in Asia.

STRANGE: We do -- we do. We actually -- we started selling into China in 2008. And then just within the last three years started in Korea.

BEVAN: How many different flavors and what's your most popular flavor?

STRANGE: We've got up over 40 flavors. Our most popular believe it or not is vanilla.

BEVAN: OK.

MALIK: Wow, not chocolate?

STRANGE: Not chocolates. So vanilla's our top flavor. Actually, what's interesting about our vanilla, it's a Philadelphia style vanilla ice cream. So Philadelphia style ice cream in general means that there's no egg yolk and whenever possible, we use very high quality Madagascar Bourbon Vanilla. This recipes -- this recipes that you're tasting there was formulated by my great grandfather.

BARTIROMO: This is awesome.

STRANGE: Thank you.

(CROSSTALK)

STRANGE: That one right there is the Mint Chocolate Chip.

BARTIROMO: Mint Chocolate Chip.

STRANGE: That's a top --

BARTIROMO: Very good.

STRANGE: That's a top flavor for us.

BEVAN: Do you have to offer like a low fat option as well or --

STRANGE: So --

BEVAN: I'm asking for myself.

BARTIROMO: Yogurt.

STRANGE: We're a high fat ice cream. 16-1/2 percent butter fat.

BARTIROMO: Oh, wow.

STRANGE: We do offer four different sorbet flavor options. But we're a through and through ice cream company.

BEVAN: Got it.

FERRIS: The '90s are over, we're not like (INAUDIBLE). It seems like an area where there's a lot of new artisanal brands coming out. I mean, every time I go like there's a bunch of nine, and eight and $10.00 pints. Is that helping this (INAUDIBLE) because there's a lot of growth in consumption or is it like digging in to like the vintage versus the more like hipster artisanal brands?

STRANGE: Well, I definitely see that the craft ice cream industry has being a really an interesting one. And it kind of -- in my mind it parallels the craft beer business. I see a lot of artisanal ice creams coming in and there's a really great community of them, especially in Philadelphia, we all work together. We -- Bassetts Ice Cream distributes some, so we have six trucks that we run distribution out of. We work with some smaller independents in the Philadelphia area. We collaborate on flavors. It's just really good and collaborative market.

FERRIS: Yes, how did you make this? And I think (INAUDIBLE) was it like lake ice from like the great lakes or something? Like, how did you even --

STRANGE: So my great, great, great grandfather was a Quaker school teacher in Salem, New Jersey, just outside of Philadelphia. And he got into the ice cream business, I guess he loved ice cream and wanted to experiment with making it. Lore is that we started churning by mule power.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

STRANGE: And then he would cart it in, horse and buggy into the farmer's markets in Philadelphia.

BARTIROMO: How great. Are you seeing any impact from the China tariffs?

STRANGE: We are. The trade war's really slowed our business down in China quite a bit. We're hopeful that we can put that behind us and get going again.

BARTIROMO: OK. Any plans for further expansion internationally? How about Europe?

STRANGE: Nothing going in Europe right now but we are looking at some other Asian countries. We actually just sent a container over to the Philippines which is pretty exciting for us. We're also talking with a couple other countries and we're loving the international stuff.

BARTIROMO: Great. Alex, it's good to have you on the program. Congratulations.

STRANGE: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes, made in America , Alex Bassett Strange, Bassetts Ice Cream.

Still ahead, Congresswoman Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar blasting Israel, going as far as to question whether it's an ally. What they said, next hour, right here, MORNINGS WITH MARIA, back in a moment.
