ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: You're looking at a live shot. It is a national day of mourning for our 41st President George Herbert Walker Bush. The plane carrying his casket just now arriving at Ellington Field in Houston, Texas.

After a brief ceremony the motorcade will proceed to St. Martin's Episcopal Church where family and friends will attend a private funeral service tomorrow. This, after a moving state funeral held today at Washington National Cathedral.

Hundreds of dignitaries, world leaders, five living presidents gathered. President Bush was celebrated with praise and humor by close friends and his son President George W. Bush broke down crying in an emotional address filled with laughter.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. This is THE EVENING EDIT.

But first, we got breaking news. G.M. CEO Mary Barra running the gauntlet in D.C. Congressmen demanding answers over G.M.'s decision to close plants in the U.S. laying off 14,000 workers.

Edward Lawrence is in Washington with the latest, let's get right to him. Edward, what's going on?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Actually, I want to tell you right now, you are not seeing me because here is the CEO of G.M., Mary Barra, coming in for her next meeting. She's meeting with the delegation from Maryland to talking about why the plant there is going -- is on the list to be slated to close.

Now she is on Capitol Hill today explaining the decision as to why G.M. has to cut 15,000 jobs and close four plants in the United States. Now she met senators from Ohio. She came, just came from a meeting with Ohio congressmen and she needs -- so she needs to restructuring of this of G.M. in order to make the company more viable and have it vibrant for the future.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARY BARRA, CEO, GENERAL MOTORS: Since 2009 we have invested $22 billion in the United States. And in the last couple of years we've invested several more billion dollars and we'll continue to do that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And what's lost in this is there are 3,000 hourly workers who will be able to move within the United States to some other plants there. That still leaves 12,000 people that will be affected by this.

Now Senator Portman says that he asked Mary Barra to put new technology in the plant at least in Ohio to try and bring that plant back to life and save some of those jobs. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ROB PORTMAN, (R) OHIO: She has said to us that she is willing to keep an open mind, but does not want to raise expectations.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now after the meeting here, tomorrow Barra will meet with the Michigan delegation in order to explain exactly what her thinking is with the company going forward. Liz?

MACDONALD: That's real shoe leather journalism, Edward. Great stuff there. Thank you so much for that report, sir. Let's get to Forbes Media chairman, Steve Forbes joins me now. Steve, what's your take on G.M. here?

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Well, I think what you see is poor timing. I think they realize that now announcing this at Thanksgiving and before Christmas. But the fact of the matter is the auto industry is very, very competitive worldwide. People are not buying passenger cars the way they used to, they like the SUVs, they like the trucks. But traditional passenger cars, they don't so much.

And so, I think they probably made the right decision, but the timing of it left something to be desired. But I do think in Lordstown they will do something to keep that plant going even if it's nowhere near the employment they had it before.

MACDONALD: Good point. Steve, let's turn to President George H.W. Bush's funeral today in Washington, D.C. A World War II hero. A man of service and integrity. He helped set the stage for the end of the Cold War era.

Here is the thing, Steve. You say that President Bush's policies also helped set the stage for the economic boom of the 90s, but he's blamed for raising taxes.

FORBES: I thought the decision to raise taxes was the wrong at that time. Still do. But he did other things, such as ending the Cold War, such as dealing with the savings and loan crisis which cost a lot of money, it was a huge strain on U.S. economy. So, he did a lot of things right.

And I think it's beginning to be appreciated today, his role in ending the Cold War without a shot being fired. Because it went so smoothly, we think that was the most of natural thing in the world. No. If he had mishandled that it would have been a disaster. And that was an enormous achievement.

What he did with the Iraq war was an enormous achievement, and so he didn't get credit at the time for those major achievements. But I think people remember him today. And I think, Liz, in the future he's going to be even more influential in death than he was in life by the example he set of service, of civility and putting the country first.

MACDONALD: Yes. You make an important point because the strong American economy equals to -- you know, is helped by a strong American policy, right? In other words, you can't have a strong American economy if you don't have strong foreign policies.

FORBES: Security is essential. That's the first--

MACDONALD: Yes.

FORBES: -- duty of a president or king or whatever. As they used to say, defense of the realm. He was cognizant of that. He did cut back after the end of the Cold War and the military but did so I think in a much more careful manner that was done subsequently.

He was well aware from living through the 30s and 40s, you have to have a good defense. Not too much, but certainly not too little. His leadership in that area I think we could have used in more recent years.

MACDONALD: Steve, you served under President George H.W. Bush as chair of the bipartisan board for international broadcasting. Can you tell us your personal thoughts and memories of the president?

FORBES: Well, he was a president who cared about the country, but he also is very personal. When my father died in early 1990, he called me, expressed condolences, have said nice things about the meetings he had with my father, he said things about what his father meant to him. Those kinds of gestures I think are what truly live.

So, it was a privilege to serve him. He understood the importance of communications and getting America's message out to the world. But he also had that personal touch that really last with you and makes the kind of impression that never leaves you.

MACDONALD: And you could see his son's personal touch too, saying, you know what, he had a horrible short game and he hated vegetables. That was funny. There were funny moments today, right, Steve?

FORBES: There were. It was a wonderful service as everyone has remark. The two and a half hours went very, very quickly. It was a good combination of humor and sadness. And I think what George W. Bush did was the perfect way to end those extraordinary eulogies starting with Meacham, right, Simpsons and the others, of Mulroney, Prime Minister Mulroney. A wonderful, wonderful eulogies to an extraordinary man.

MACDONALD: And Prince Charles representing her majesty the queen who visited with George H.W. Bush and Barbara Bush in 1991. And back then you know, George H.W. Bush was poking fun at the queen. He said, Steve, at the time, you know, you have your, you know, very competitive walking agenda. You had our secret serviceman out of breath trying to keep up with you. The queen.

FORBES: He had that -- he had that personal touch. He could combine seriousness of state with the humorous touches that make for personal relations. And it was personal relations that help in the Cold War in a peaceable way that it did.

Gorbachev learned to trust him. The former head of then declining Soviet Union. He didn't lord it over him. He may practice the diplomacy in a way that this thing could have gone as well as it could. And the idea 10 years before if you'd said that if we're going to win the Cold War without a shot being fired in the peaceful way that it was done, Germany would be reunited as part of NATO and we'd wage a war in the Middle East with the allies from 28 other, 29 other nations, you would have said impossible. But he brought it off.

MACDONALD: All right. Steve Forbes, chair of Forbes Media, great to see you, sir. Thank you so much.

FORBES: Thank you.

MACDONALD: We are joined now by Republican North Dakota Senator John Hoeven. It's great to see you, senator. Thanks for coming in. You attended the funeral today. Can you tell us to what you remember most about today's service?

SEN. JOHN HOEVEN, (R) NORTH DAKOTA: Liz, you know, it was remarkable. The music was incredible. The military, not only the Marine Corps symphony, but also the corps, (Inaudible) corps, the singers, but the presenters were outstanding. But clearly, Bush 43's presentation I think incredibly powerful, particularly when he said about his father. He was the finest father a son could have and he choke up a little bit.

There wasn't a dry eye in the cathedral, there wasn't dry anywhere. It was really powerful.

MACDONALD: Yes, we were covering it on set of Varney, Stuart Varney show and we had tears in our eyes seeing President George W. Bush break down like that and cry. You could see that he was trying to keep it in, right, senator. That he was trying to hold back but when he said and got to the point the last words that his father said in this world were "I love you" to his son, that's when the tears started flowing, right, sir?

HOEVEN: Liz, exactly. You know, President Bush 43 is a strong man and he showed it. You know, you could see he was going through the eulogy and he want to do a good job for his dad. And you know, that final moment, and he was so strong all the way through it.

In that final moment where he said, you know, he was the finest father a son could have, and you know, he choked up at that point. It just that resonated with people. It captured his father. It captured their love. It was really a beautiful moment.

MACDONALD: And dignitaries from around the world were there. We were talking just early about Prince Charles representing her Majesty the Queen.

HOEVEN: Right.

MACDONALD: Also, Angela Merkel, King Hussein of Jordan.

HOEVEN: Right.

MACDONALD: And former British Prime Minister John Major, I mean, he was respected around the world, right, sir?

HOEVEN: Well, that was one of his strengths, right? I mean, his relationships with leaders around the world, and of course, look at his resume before he was president. I mean, he was at the U.N., he was CIA director. He was envoy to China. But that personal touch, I mean, I have a letter from him, you know, which I treasure. And I mean, he reached out to everybody and it was genuine and it was real and he certainly did that on the world stage.

And I think there are leaders across the globe, you know, that still really admire and appreciate George Herbert Walker Bush.

MACDONALD: Senator Hoeven, thank you so much for coming in, sir. We really appreciate it.

HOEVEN: Great to be with you.

MACDONALD: Now what not many may realize is the huge impact President George H.W. Bush had on the Supreme Court, a lasting effect we still feel today.

Let's bring in Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. You point out that he nominated two justices that paved the way for two more.

ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Two very opposite justices. One of whom greatly displeased him and one of them pleased him beyond his wildest imagining. So, David Souter, a patrician Republican like George W. Bush from New England turned out to be the darling of the liberals.

On the side of abortion rights, on the side of expanding congressional regulation of economic rights and famously or infamously on the side of eminent domain whereby the government can seize property, and then sell it to the higher bidder even if it's not going to be put to a public use. The famous Kelo versus New London, Connecticut case. On the other hand, there's Clarence Thomas.

MACDONALD: Right. And is he the longest serving justice on the court right now?

NAPOLITANO: Yes, he is.

MACDONALD: Yes. OK.

NAPOLITANO: He is the senior justice for 27 years. He has shocked even his adversaries, and even his adversaries have praised his work. How do I know this? So, when you teach law school, you use a casebook, about 1500 pages. And it's the cases that first and second year law students need to know.

Flipping through the constitutional criminal procedure casebook and I see opinions by Justice Clarence Thomas. And then I look at the author, the editor of the casebook. Some of the most liberal intelligentsia in the legal community showing respect for the work of Clarence Thomas.

MACDONALD: So, he knew the guys to pick, right? I mean, you also point out--

(CROSSTALK)

NAPOLITANO: I don't know that he could--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: But John Roberts and Samuel Alito he appointed too.

NAPOLITANO: Well, he appointed Mr. John Roberts to the circuit Court of Appeals and he appointed Mr. Samuel Alito to the circuit Court of Appeals. From each of which they ascended to the Supreme Court by his son.

So, I don't know that he could have expected that Justice Thomas would serve as well and as long as he has. here's another little tidbit. This is probably driving Justice Scalia in heaven crazy.

Justice Thomas has more--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Who you knew.

NAPOLITANO: Yes. And I could him about this is he were here. Justice Thomas, Justice Clarence Thomas has more of his own clerks now as federal judges and senior administrators in the nonpolitical appointee in the civil service side of the government than any other justice in the modern era.

Acolytes of his small government, maximum individual liberty dial back the regulators.

MACDONALD: Steve Forbes and John Hoeven. Senator Hoeven is still here. Steve, can you react to just what Judge Napolitano is saying about President George H.W.'s impact on the Supreme Court.

FORBES: Well, I think the judge has summarized it very well and Clarence Thomas being on for as long as he has been, has had that influence. And the fact is that the media just ignores what the impact that he has. And so, you don't read in the public press much about him but he's had the kind of impact that I think George H.W. Bush would've chuckle and appreciated somebody who is a laid-back as the Thomas's as George H.W. Bush was, and but made a huge impact.

Sometimes a less can be so much more. And there are those two are examples of it.

MACDONALD: Senator Hoeven, come in on this. What's your -- you were seeing now the Bush family leaving the plane.

Can you react to what Steve Forbes and Judge Napolitano was just saying, Senator Hoven about the impact in the Supreme Court?

HOEVEN: Absolutely, I totally agree with him. And you know, it's interesting to watch as a family comes off Air Force One. When I've actually flown both President Bush 43 and Present Trump on Air Force One and to see that magnificent aircraft carrying President Bush and the Bush family it's amazing.

You know, but definitely no question that it's been a profound impact on the court.

MACDONALD: You know, you have personal anecdotes, Judge Napolitano. You met George H.W. Bush, right?

NAPOLITANO: Well, the George H.W. Bush that I met was after his presidency. He twice teased me about my height, of course, almost everybody is sure that President George H.W. Bush.

MACDONALD: What did he say?

NAPOLITANO: And listen to this. He was -- so Steve will love and so with the senator. He was twice admonished by Barbara for it. And Barbara just to him, you know, you all guys you think you're superior to people from Princeton. Steve knows about this. They have an incredible superiority complex. Totally undeserved.

But you know, it was the type of warmth you didn't expect from this patrician. Everything everybody is saying about him about amiability and kindness and warmth was what I observed in the two times that I met him, both after he was out of office.

MACDONALD: Forgive me, Steve for being a little -- I might be a little arts here, but it gets breathtakingly tedious to hear conversations like we've lost that demeanor and that positioning of just being of kindness and humility and integrity and service.

I still think that there are people in this country who are like that. It's not as if all -- everybody is talking like all is lost. D.C. is gone forever into a pit of just terrible ways of behaving. What do you say?

FORBES: I think by his example and the reminder that his death underlines that example, those traits will live on. That's why his influence is going to be perhaps even greater than it was when he was in the White House is by the example he set.

So, it's out there. The American people has response to it today. I think exemplifies the fact, underscores the fact that people like this kind of a behavior, have like that kind of example of a service with humility. So, it's there today, and I think you are going to see more of it in the future--

MACDONALD: You know--

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: -- because of George H.W. Bush.

MACDONALD: Senator Hoeven, you were there, you were at the funeral. I was taken by biographer John Meacham recounting the president's love for his life as George W. Bush exits with the first lady Barbara Bush -- excuse me, Laura Bush who set an enduring example of elegance and stability. First lady Laura Bush there.

He called, you know, he, George H.W. called Barbara the silver fox and when the situation warranted the enforcer, so they're pretty honest about their roles in the family, right, Senator Hoeven?

HOEVEN: No question about it. You know, I run into quite a few couples that are maybe married 50 years. Some that are married 60 years. Very few 70 over 70 years, and in their case 73 years. He called her Bar, the silver fox or the enforcer. And it's humorous to hear him talk about her in that enforcer role.

But listen to Bush 43 talk about her in that same capacity or Jeb and they'll tell you the same thing.

MACDONALD: Yes. What did you think of this comment, I mean, there was a lot of touching moments today at the funeral, right, judge?

NAPOLITANO: I thought it was deeply moving. I thought Meacham was brilliant and Senator John Meacham was brilliant and Senator Meacham -- and Senator Simpson was hilarious and George H. Bush made everybody's get goosebumps when he wept the way he did.

MACDONALD: You can still see George W. Bush in this live shot holding it back. You could still see his struggle to keep the emotions.

NAPOLITANO: He's a very emotional guy.

MACDONALD: Yes, he is. He's cried at the wounded soldiers.

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

MACDONALD: He cried at the opening of his library. And first, Steve Forbes, first lady Laura Bush, you could visibly move today. You could see that in camera.

FORBES: And I think that's what added so much to the ceremony was, yes, George H.W. Bush was president, but he was also a fantastic father and it's no secret Bush 43, he had a very troubled time when he was younger. And it was the understanding, firmness and understanding of his father that help him mature into the great man he became.

And so, what it shows that you stick with it. That you will have these firm principles but know how to apply them, know how to do it with love and the results are amazing.

MACDONALD: And we also -- yes, go ahead, sir.

FORBES: And the loss -- and the loss of a father like that we don't want to get as you say treat you to idealistic, but that's the kind of model that parent should look to. Having principles, firmness but also love and understanding when the kids sometimes get into a rough spot.

MACDONALD: You are--

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: They'll get out of it with proper guidance.

MACDONALD: A civilizing force of the first lady Laura Bush.

FORBES: Yes.

MACDONALD: You are watching a live shot. Again, viewers, if you are just joining us now of Ellington Field in Houston. The president's casket is now with the honor service being -- exiting the carrier to come down to go to a motorcade and then there will be a private funeral in Houston, Texas.

You know, every living president, five of them were there, Judge Napolitano.

NAPOLITANO: Right.

MACDONALD: And, you know--

NAPOLITANO: And every vice president since 1970 was there.

MACDONALD: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: Except for George H.W. Bush.

MACDONALD: Yes, except Walter Mondale.

NAPOLITANO: Even Walter Mondale. I think Mondale was there.

MACDONALD: He attended Wednesday, sir, yes.

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

MACDONALD: Yes, he did.

NAPOLITANO: I'm not talking about now. I'm talking about the one when the senator was at the Washington National Cathedral.

MACDONALD: Let's take a moment to listen to the flourishes here.

(MUSIC PLAYING)

MACDONALD: Viewers, if you are joining us now, you are watching the ceremony at Ellington Field as the casket of President George H.W. Bush has arrived in Houston, Texas. It will head over to lie in repose at St. Martin's Episcopal Church.

Let's get back to Senator John Hoven. You know, the point when, senator, you were at the funeral today when George W. Bush as we're watching this ceremony in Ellington Field, he said, George W. Bush is still clearly trying to hold back tears, and so was the first lady. That moment when he broke down it is so hard to watch somebody hold back their tears and then break down when they read and an emotionally moving statement, right, senator?

HOEVEN: Absolutely. And you can see he's still, you know, struggling. It became so apparent that as he made his wonderful presentation and it really was fantastic that he was, you know, he wants to be very strong and he was.

But again, when he came to that special moment talking about how wonderful -- what his father meant to him and he broke down for just a second. Again, it was so emotionally powerful. Everybody could feel it. Men and women, there was not a dry eye in the cathedral.

MACDONALD: Yes, I could understand that. And his three -- President George H.W. Bush's three grandchildren. The three granddaughters were wonderful today too, Steve Forbes, John Meacham, who eulogize also former first lady Barbara Bush earlier this year. He was wonderfully funny, Steve.

He recalls, for example, a really funny anecdotes George H.W. Bush out on the campaign trail, shaking hands with everybody accidentally shaking hands with a department store mannequin in New Hampshire. And he said when he realized his mistake George W. -- H.W. said, well, you'll never know, I got to ask. It was a funny, funny moment.

FORBES: Yes. And online more than one person observed in certain parts of America they would be voters, so the humor out there in our great country is still there even in a solemn moment like this. Another thing to keep in mind, Liz, in all of this is that George H.W. Bush is also our greatest baseball president.

He loved the game, play the game well when he was in college, Yale, he went twice to the College World Series and he had amazing store of anecdotes and the statistics about baseball. He was like, there's a great store in the Boston Globe today by Dan Shaughnessy about George H.W. Bush's love of baseball. How is like a little kid seeing a great baseball player like Bobby Doerr of the Red Sox from the 1930s and 40s.

And that part of him again we didn't fully appreciate. But baseball has been the national past time and this president appreciated it more and understood it better than any other president. When he was watching a game, he was recounted he would always be anticipating what the players would do and he understood the glories of baseball, and that's just another feather in an extraordinary cup of George H.W. Bush.

MACDONALD: Final word, Senator Hoeven.

HOEVEN: Well, that said, I mean he epitomize love of country, service, loyalty, family, things that we all respect and honor and appreciate.

MACDONALD: The nation says goodbye to George H.W. Bush. Thank you so much, Senator Hoeven and Steve Forbes. I really appreciate your insights tonight.

HOEVEN: Thank you.

FORBES: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Thanks for joining us. Let's get to the markets. Futures are trading down 178 points right now after the massive selloff, nearly 800 points yesterday. We're going to have more on the markets after the break. We've got a jampacked rest of the show for you. Stay right there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: OK, yesterday, we lost almost 800 points. The action in the futures is not looking good right now. Nearly 200-point futures sell off. That means nearly a thousand points in two days. We are staying on this for you. Futures don't necessarily indicate what the markets will end at the close of tomorrow's trading, but we're going to stay on it for you.

OK, let's get back to this story for you. Big tech behaving badly again. The Washington Post slamming Google suggesting it is doing "evil" by building a censored search engine for China that can spy on citizens. The U.K., Britain, exposes even more Facebook controversies, fresh ones, in another big reveal of internal documents.

We need one of the best cyber pros around to break it all down, Leeza Garber. So, great to see you, Leeza.

LEEZA GARBER, CYBERSECURITY EXPERT: Hi, Liz. Great to see you and I'm smiling, but this is not great news. It's not a good story.

(LAUGHTER)

MACDONALD: Yeah, but Google -- take on Google first.

GARBER: So Google really has been pivoting its position on China. At first, it says way back in 2006, we are going to go in, we are going to bring up the search engine, bring the internet to everybody. Not only is it altruistic but there's a lot of money to be made in that market. There is a lot of the world's population in China.

But at the same time, the Chinese government has some censorship issues and then additionally, what is the Chinese government's role going to be and how Google operates there? Are they going to have access to what citizens are searching? Things like that. So there is a surveillance question as well.

Google's CEO continues to take a different public position against what Google employees are saying we should be in China, we shouldn't be in China.

MACDONALD: Right.

GARBER: Those are the problems.

MACDONALD: And so, you know, Google shut it down in 2006. The CEO, the executive saying, hey, China is not only surveilling and spying but also hacking into citizens' Gmails. (INAUDIBLE) but now they're doing it again. I don't get that. Let's get to Facebook because this is a big story. The U.K. had seized internal Facebook documents and e-mails and it found now another big reveal that yes, Facebook was selling access to user data.

Remember, Mark Zuckerberg said we don't sell user data but it looks like they're selling access. Even worse, according the to the e-mails, that it build some kind of spyware, Facebook did, that could basically take out (ph) your user data information without you knowing about it. And also basically in android devices recording the history of who you are texting and calling. That's what Facebook was doing.

GARBER: Facebook is in the middle of a couple different significant ethical issues right now. It is not just in terms of the consumers of the application itself, but it's consumers of devices that house the application.

So there are different secretive agreements going on with android manufacturers, with different application developers in terms of what kind of data they can garner from users of Facebook, if they're using an Android phone, if they use different apps that are available.

MACDONALD: Both Google and Facebook are free. That's what people will say, then you say to yourself, OK, then users are the products, so maybe we should be called suppliers and not users, right?

GARBER: Exactly. If it's free, you are the product. There is no question. I mean , we are day by day giving up so much personal data that is so valuable. And at the end of the day, Facebook is an advertising company. They are advertising to us 24/7.

MACDONALD: So what's the limit to that? If you take the other side of that argument, people saying, you know, you have this kind of benign kind of aspect toward Facebook. You know, if you go to a medical clinic and medical clinics, we hope, are not distributing your blood records, right, or things about you, or insurance companies.

GARBER: Exactly. It's a scary analogy because at one -- at some perspective, Facebook is doing a valuable service. It is good. We get to interact with people. There is a good there.

MACDONALD: You're checking on your family and friends.

GARBER: Right, exactly. Share photos and ideas. In that way, it is a great platform. But on the other side, and this is something the United States is struggling with, is the data privacy aspect. What is interesting about this release of documents is it came from the U.K.

MACDONALD: OK.

GARBER: So the E.U. has the new privacy regulations. The U.S. is lagging behind.

MACDONALD: We got to take a quick break. Stay right there. We are going to have more on the show. Join us in the second.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Let's take a check at the futures. Look at this. It is worsening. The futures are trending down 244 points to yesterday's drop in the markets. That is over a thousand points. We are staying on that story for you as it develops.

Let's get to the next case. Russian President Vladimir Putin warns the United States that if it does walk out of the key Cold War arms treaty and starts developing missiles banned by that treaty, that Russia will do the same. This a day after Secretary of State Michael Pompeo announced that Russia has 60 days to come clean about cheating under that treaty.

Let's take it up with Fox News contributor, retired U.S. Army Major General Robert Scales. Good to see you, sir.

ROBERT SCALES, RETIRED U.S. ARMY MAJOR GENERAL: Hi, Liz.

MACDONALD: So this treaty kept the peace for 30 years now. What is going on? I mean, apparently the U.S. has intelligence that Russia has a nuclear cruise missile that can hit Europe with little or no notice.

SCALES: Well, actually, the Russian nuclear missile program comes in two flavors. One is a rocket which exceeds the INF Treaty limit of 300 miles. And the other issue, say, is a cruise missile. The Russians have been at this really since about 2011.

There is no new news here. All 27 NATO nations agree that the Russians are cheating just like they cheated in Ukraine, they cheated in Georgia, and they lied about interfering with our elections in 2016. If Mr. Putin opens his mouth, he is lying.

MACDONALD: So general, are you worried about this?

SCALES: No, not at all. A couple of quick points. First of all, Putin has as you may have heard, has threatened that this may lead to a new nuclear arms race. Well, that's impossible. Russia doesn't have the military resources or the money to even begin to threaten the United States with an arms race.

Secondly, the United States started its own refurbishment of its nuclear programs and is well ahead of the Russians in that category. The third thing, both sides have got 7,000 nuclear weapons. The last thing the world needs is a brand newly minted Russian nuclear weapon. The INF is going to die in about 60 days. There is very little that Vladimir Putin can do to keep that treaty alive.

MACDONALD: Analysts say Russia sees the weapons as a cheaper alternative to conventional forces. Does that concern you?

SCALES: No. A little military 101, Liz. Increasingly as we've seen over the last 20 years or so, the battlefield is beginning to expand, whether it's naval power, air power or land power. That's very much the case in Europe. Now that the American military is focused increasingly on a peer conflict with Russia, the battlefield has extended beyond the INF.

So whether it's a conventional rocket or a nuclear weapon, the battlefield, the dynamics of war have grown beyond the treaty. The Russians understand that and we understand it. The United States is already beginning to develop artillery and rockets that go beyond -- at least rockets that go beyond 300 miles. This is a normal evolution of the course of war and we should not be worried about it.

MACDONALD: General, we're going to switch gear. Let's go to what is going on with China and the trade deal. I hate to hit you with this, but China's Huawei technology is again under fire. The United Kingdom's big telecommunications company, BT, yanked out of its core of its network Huawei equipment.

The trade deal clearly, the negotiations rocking the markets right now. The futures indicating down another 240 points right there. Nearly a 1,000- point drop in two days. Investors are poring through and looking through the China trade negotiations. Trump says one thing, the Chinese say another. What's your take in all of this?

SCALES: Well, I have to say something. Frankly, the Chinese have never been straight up about anything they do. As a soldier, I can tell you that their approach to stealing our military secrets, I guess, is a legend, at least within the Department of Defense. They do the same thing with our technology.

There is very little that one can trust about the statistics on Chinese business about their policies that deal with finance. They have always been less than honest when dealing with the rest of the world. What's happening now, Liz, is all of that is coming home to roost. Unfortunately, the American investors are suffering in the short term.

MACDONALD: General, is President Trump the right man to take them on?

SCALES: Absolutely because no president in the last 20, 25 years has stood up to the Chinese because they always believe that if China's markets can open up, if they become entrepreneurial, that democracy will follow.

And I think you will agree with me, what's been proven over the last 20 years is that's not necessarily so. The Chinese have developed a way to enrich their country. At the same time, remain a totalitarian state. And we have to come to grips with that, Liz.

MACDONALD: Are you optimistic we will get a deal with China?

SCALES: Oh, I think so. First of all, it's more in China's best interest to get a deal than it is in the United States' interest right now because China has more to lose, Liz.

MACDONALD: Yeah, that's a good point. It is in recessionary mode. Its markets are in the bear market. Major General Scales, thank you so much for joining us. Really appreciate it.

SCALES: Thank you, Liz.

MACDONALD: Back to the futures, down more than 240 points after the Dow lost almost 800 points yesterday. Let's bring in our money pro, Michael Lee of Altium Wealth Management. He joins me now on phone. Michael, are you worried? Are you going to be buying or selling tomorrow?

MICHAEL LEE, MARKET STRATEGIST, ALTIUM WEALTH MANAGEMENT (via telephone): Liz, I will be looking to buy. I think we have two competing narratives going on right now. I think they are both wrong. But they are dominating the conversation. First is the FED will raise rates too high and too fast and cause a recession. The second narrative is that the FED will stop raising rates because growth is slowing so dramatically.

MACDONALD: Is growth slowing dramatically? I mean, are you in the bear camp that you see recession?

LEE (via telephone): No. I think a recession is years away. We obviously will have a recession at some point in the future, but no time -- not in 2019 and most likely not in 2020. And people that are looking for -- looking to predict such an occurrence, there is no real evidence out there other than what is going on in the media narrative.

I think volatility is here to stay. I think these two, one and a half, two to three percent moves are coming but that doesn't necessarily mean that stocks will continue to go down.

MACDONALD: I'm sorry but -- I hear what you are saying. We came off in a period of historic complacency, zero volatility last year, so one, two percent historically moved, that is not a big deal. Are you optimistic the president will get a trade deal? A lot of naysayers out there, they are missing this point, Michael.

President Trump has aligned his legacy closely with the market performance, and he will not allow that market to drop. He will grab that trade deal as soon as he can, as soon as it is a good one for the United States. What do you think?

LEE (via telephone): Liz, in terms of trade with China, this is going to be a long drawn out street fight. What we want will ultimately benefit China and that's to open up their markets. They need the foreign investment and they need to be a global trader. They can't have a closed economy.

MACDONALD: All right. I think -- is Deirdre Bolton ready to go again?

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: I swept in.

MACDONALD: You did. Deirdre, what is going on 263 down?

BOLTON: Two sixty-three down. So I think it is a lot of way you've been talking about with your guests. That is to say there is a of traders in. Liz, you were speaking with them too right yesterday in the sell-off. The subtotal was what exactly happened in Buenos Aires? We know that this trade tensions have this kind of 90-day window where they are frozen. But there is a lot of investors who don't know what that means after.

A lot of people I am reaching out are saying we still don't know exactly which industries are going to be affected or in which ways. Of course, we heard this kind of silver lining possibilities, right?

We heard actually President Trump tweeting out earlier, referencing an article that Bloomberg had written saying the Chinese have agreed to start buying industrial products, have agreed to start buying liquid natural gas, have agreed to start buying -- the implication was soybeans. In fact, actually they didn't even name that precisely.

So it seems as if things are moving in the right direction but still no precision. So I think that anxiety and those worries are what showed up for the huge market day sell-off yesterday. It is what is affecting our futures right now. We have a global sell-off too.

We know our markets of course are closed today in honor of former President Bush but the rest of the world was trading. It was a rough day out there. It was a rough day in Europe. It was a rough day in Asia. And I think a lot of other countries, Liz, are looking at what is going on between us and China. I mean, we are the world's two largest economies, right?

MACDONALD: Yeah.

BOLTON: So, if there does seem to be this kind of lack of precision and vagary about what is coming in the next 90 days, all that means for people is, they don't know what is happening again for the next three months, Liz.

MACDONALD: That's a good point. I mean, Deirdre, here is the other thing that is going one. We got breaking news, Deirdre. Sit tight. Let's get right to Edward Lawrence with an exclusive interview. Edward?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Not everyone. There are a total of 15,000 basically the job cuts as you mentioned, but not everyone is losing their job, right?

MARY BARRA, CEO, GM: There is definitely opportunity for many of the workers to work in other factories around the country that are growing. That is our focus. We understand that it's a very difficult time. It's a very difficult announcement to make.

We are really focused on making sure they understand the situation, they know the options open to them, and that is where our focus is right now. I really was pleased to have an opportunity to speak with many of the representatives from Maryland to be able to understand their issues. We'll move forward and make sure we stay in good connection, but our focus right is on the workers.

LAWRENCE: Some people say the 21 percent tax is what the cut went to for corporate tax, could use some of that money to save some of these jobs. Was there one thing to you that said, you know, we have to make these changes?

BARRA: This industry is transforming and we need to make sure that General Motors is around for you the next several decades. We have responsibilities to many of our stakeholders, our employees, folks who retired from the company, our investors. And so we are trying to make sure that we have a strong General Motors that is going to be ready and lead in a rapidly changing transportation market.

LAWRENCE: What about bringing new technology? Senator Portman talked about bringing the new technology, electric cars, to possibly revive some of these plants?

BARRA: We build electric cars. I am very proud of the Chevrolet Bolt EV that we built in Lake Orion, Michigan. It is doing very well. In fact, we are expanding capacity there to build more of those vehicles. So, we are bringing new technology. We also in that same plant build the test vehicles for autonomous vehicles.

So, we are bringing new technology, that engineering work is developed here. And over the last several years, we brought many of our engineering jobs and many of our IT jobs back to the United States from many countries around the world. It is something that we have invested in here.

LAWRENCE: Will you look at those plants? Moving some of those --

BARRA: You know, we are going to work with our union. These plants are unallocated right now. I have a responsibility to work the UAW on that.

LAWRENCE: Thank you very much. I appreciate it. Thank you very much. I appreciate your time.

So there you have it. Mary Barra leaving the meeting today with Maryland delegation. Tomorrow, she is actually going to meet with the Michigan delegation there. So a lot of news that lawmakers here are trying to get her to possibly save some of these jobs, reallocate as you heard some of the money and technology into some of these plants that might be closed.

We will just have to see how this all plays out. Again, this seems to have united both Republicans and Democrats who obviously don't want to see job losses in their districts.

MACDONALD: Yeah, tough story. Ed Lawrence is giving breaking news on this all day. Thank you so much, Edward Lawrence. Great reporting there. Let's take a commercial break. We are going to be right back. Stay right there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. You're not going to believe this story. Massachusetts Republican Governor Charlie Baker now calling for a state judge to be temporarily removed. Why? She helped an illegal, Jose Perez, sneak out the backdoor of a courthouse where federal ICE agents wanted to arrest him in the front of the courthouse.

Let's bring in Bristol County, Massachusetts sheriff, Thomas Hodgson. Sir, this is outrageous stuff.

THOMAS HODGSON, SHERIFF, BRISTOL COUNTY, MA: Liz, this is as bad as it gets. You know, about a year and and a half ago, I testified before the judiciary down in Washington before Congress. I remember Congressman King asked me, Steve King said, sheriff, what should be done for these people who are harboring and concealing people they know to be in the country illegally?

And I said there's only one thing to do, congressman, issue arrest warrants on them. Frankly, this judge and what she did, in a calculating way, undermined not only law enforcement but undermined the people in the community who trust her to do everything that she can as a judge to make sure the communities are safe.

MACDONALD: Yeah, there is a grand jury probe to get to the bottom of the allegations. He is a multiple offender. He was arrested and deported multiple times for drug charges. We have heard judges obstructing justice before. I do not understand how judges can get away with that, sheriff.

HODGSON: That is the problem. Until we start really cracking down on whether it is judges or whether it is elected officials, look, Title Eight is clear. Anyone who attempts to harbor or conceal someone they know to be in the country illegally commits a felony under federal law.

And so in this instance where this judge did this, what's worse about this Liz, is that this individual was operating under three false identifications, which is identity fraud, which is a felony.

But the judge was aware of this and then to know that the person to be deported twice was operating under three different identifications and then let them, bring them downstairs and out the backdoor and scale the fence to get away, is completely outrageous. And to think a judge would do this completely sort of undermines the confidence people have in our justice system.

MACDONALD: If it is true, they should throw the book at her. Thank you, Sheriff Hodgson, and thank you for your service to our country. Well, we had a jam-packed hour. A lot of news in the show. Thank you so much for having us in your homes and thank you for watching. Lou Dobbs is next right here on Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

END

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: You're looking at a live shot. It is a national day of mourning for our 41st President George Herbert Walker Bush. The plane carrying his casket just now arriving at Ellington Field in Houston, Texas.

After a brief ceremony the motorcade will proceed to St. Martin's Episcopal Church where family and friends will attend a private funeral service tomorrow. This, after a moving state funeral held today at Washington National Cathedral.

Hundreds of dignitaries, world leaders, five living presidents gathered. President Bush was celebrated with praise and humor by close friends and his son President George W. Bush broke down crying in an emotional address filled with laughter.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. This is THE EVENING EDIT.

But first, we got breaking news. G.M. CEO Mary Barra running the gauntlet in D.C. Congressmen demanding answers over G.M.'s decision to close plants in the U.S. laying off 14,000 workers.

Edward Lawrence is in Washington with the latest, let's get right to him. Edward, what's going on?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Actually, I want to tell you right now, you are not seeing me because here is the CEO of G.M., Mary Barra, coming in for her next meeting. She's meeting with the delegation from Maryland to talking about why the plant there is going -- is on the list to be slated to close.

Now she is on Capitol Hill today explaining the decision as to why G.M. has to cut 15,000 jobs and close four plants in the United States. Now she met senators from Ohio. She came, just came from a meeting with Ohio congressmen and she needs -- so she needs to restructuring of this of G.M. in order to make the company more viable and have it vibrant for the future.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARY BARRA, CEO, GENERAL MOTORS: Since 2009 we have invested $22 billion in the United States. And in the last couple of years we've invested several more billion dollars and we'll continue to do that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And what's lost in this is there are 3,000 hourly workers who will be able to move within the United States to some other plants there. That still leaves 12,000 people that will be affected by this.

Now Senator Portman says that he asked Mary Barra to put new technology in the plant at least in Ohio to try and bring that plant back to life and save some of those jobs. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ROB PORTMAN, (R) OHIO: She has said to us that she is willing to keep an open mind, but does not want to raise expectations.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now after the meeting here, tomorrow Barra will meet with the Michigan delegation in order to explain exactly what her thinking is with the company going forward. Liz?

MACDONALD: That's real shoe leather journalism, Edward. Great stuff there. Thank you so much for that report, sir. Let's get to Forbes Media chairman, Steve Forbes joins me now. Steve, what's your take on G.M. here?

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Well, I think what you see is poor timing. I think they realize that now announcing this at Thanksgiving and before Christmas. But the fact of the matter is the auto industry is very, very competitive worldwide. People are not buying passenger cars the way they used to, they like the SUVs, they like the trucks. But traditional passenger cars, they don't so much.

And so, I think they probably made the right decision, but the timing of it left something to be desired. But I do think in Lordstown they will do something to keep that plant going even if it's nowhere near the employment they had it before.

MACDONALD: Good point. Steve, let's turn to President George H.W. Bush's funeral today in Washington, D.C. A World War II hero. A man of service and integrity. He helped set the stage for the end of the Cold War era.

Here is the thing, Steve. You say that President Bush's policies also helped set the stage for the economic boom of the 90s, but he's blamed for raising taxes.

FORBES: I thought the decision to raise taxes was the wrong at that time. Still do. But he did other things, such as ending the Cold War, such as dealing with the savings and loan crisis which cost a lot of money, it was a huge strain on U.S. economy. So, he did a lot of things right.

And I think it's beginning to be appreciated today, his role in ending the Cold War without a shot being fired. Because it went so smoothly, we think that was the most of natural thing in the world. No. If he had mishandled that it would have been a disaster. And that was an enormous achievement.

What he did with the Iraq war was an enormous achievement, and so he didn't get credit at the time for those major achievements. But I think people remember him today. And I think, Liz, in the future he's going to be even more influential in death than he was in life by the example he set of service, of civility and putting the country first.

MACDONALD: Yes. You make an important point because the strong American economy equals to -- you know, is helped by a strong American policy, right? In other words, you can't have a strong American economy if you don't have strong foreign policies.

FORBES: Security is essential. That's the first--

MACDONALD: Yes.

So it seems as if things are moving in the right direction but still no precision. So I think that anxiety and those worries are what showed up for the huge market day sell-off yesterday. It is what is affecting our futures right now. We have a global sell-off too.

We know our markets of course are closed today in honor of former President Bush but the rest of the world was trading. It was a rough day out there. It was a rough day in Europe. It was a rough day in Asia. And I think a lot of other countries, Liz, are looking at what is going on between us and China. I mean, we are the world's two largest economies, right?

MACDONALD: Yeah.

BOLTON: So, if there does seem to be this kind of lack of precision and vagary about what is coming in the next 90 days, all that means for people is, they don't know what is happening again for the next three months, Liz.

MACDONALD: That's a good point. I mean, Deirdre, here is the other thing that is going one. We got breaking news, Deirdre. Sit tight. Let's get right to Edward Lawrence with an exclusive interview. Edward?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Not everyone. There are a total of 15,000 basically the job cuts as you mentioned, but not everyone is losing their job, right?

MARY BARRA, CEO, GM: There is definitely opportunity for many of the workers to work in other factories around the country that are growing. That is our focus. We understand that it's a very difficult time. It's a very difficult announcement to make.

We are really focused on making sure they understand the situation, they know the options open to them, and that is where our focus is right now. I really was pleased to have an opportunity to speak with many of the representatives from Maryland to be able to understand their issues. We'll move forward and make sure we stay in good connection, but our focus right is on the workers.

LAWRENCE: Some people say the 21 percent tax is what the cut went to for corporate tax, could use some of that money to save some of these jobs. Was there one thing to you that said, you know, we have to make these changes?

BARRA: This industry is transforming and we need to make sure that General Motors is around for you the next several decades. We have responsibilities to many of our stakeholders, our employees, folks who retired from the company, our investors. And so we are trying to make sure that we have a strong General Motors that is going to be ready and lead in a rapidly changing transportation market.

LAWRENCE: What about bringing new technology? Senator Portman talked about bringing the new technology, electric cars, to possibly revive some of these plants?

BARRA: We build electric cars. I am very proud of the Chevrolet Bolt EV that we built in Lake Orion, Michigan. It is doing very well. In fact, we are expanding capacity there to build more of those vehicles. So, we are bringing new technology. We also in that same plant build the test vehicles for autonomous vehicles.

So, we are bringing new technology, that engineering work is developed here. And over the last several years, we brought many of our engineering jobs and many of our IT jobs back to the United States from many countries around the world. It is something that we have invested in here.

LAWRENCE: Will you look at those plants? Moving some of those --

BARRA: You know, we are going to work with our union. These plants are unallocated right now. I have a responsibility to work the UAW on that.

LAWRENCE: Thank you very much. I appreciate it. Thank you very much. I appreciate your time.

So there you have it. Mary Barra leaving the meeting today with Maryland delegation. Tomorrow, she is actually going to meet with the Michigan delegation there. So a lot of news that lawmakers here are trying to get her to possibly save some of these jobs, reallocate as you heard some of the money and technology into some of these plants that might be closed.

We will just have to see how this all plays out. Again, this seems to have united both Republicans and Democrats who obviously don't want to see job losses in their districts.

MACDONALD: Yeah, tough story. Ed Lawrence is giving breaking news on this all day. Thank you so much, Edward Lawrence. Great reporting there. Let's take a commercial break. We are going to be right back. Stay right there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. You're not going to believe this story. Massachusetts Republican Governor Charlie Baker now calling for a state judge to be temporarily removed. Why? She helped an illegal, Jose Perez, sneak out the backdoor of a courthouse where federal ICE agents wanted to arrest him in the front of the courthouse.

Let's bring in Bristol County, Massachusetts sheriff, Thomas Hodgson. Sir, this is outrageous stuff.

THOMAS HODGSON, SHERIFF, BRISTOL COUNTY, MA: Liz, this is as bad as it gets. You know, about a year and and a half ago, I testified before the judiciary down in Washington before Congress. I remember Congressman King asked me, Steve King said, sheriff, what should be done for these people who are harboring and concealing people they know to be in the country illegally?

And I said there's only one thing to do, congressman, issue arrest warrants on them. Frankly, this judge and what she did, in a calculating way, undermined not only law enforcement but undermined the people in the community who trust her to do everything that she can as a judge to make sure the communities are safe.

MACDONALD: Yeah, there is a grand jury probe to get to the bottom of the allegations. He is a multiple offender. He was arrested and deported multiple times for drug charges. We have heard judges obstructing justice before. I do not understand how judges can get away with that, sheriff.

HODGSON: That is the problem. Until we start really cracking down on whether it is judges or whether it is elected officials, look, Title Eight is clear. Anyone who attempts to harbor or conceal someone they know to be in the country illegally commits a felony under federal law.

And so in this instance where this judge did this, what's worse about this Liz, is that this individual was operating under three false identifications, which is identity fraud, which is a felony.

But the judge was aware of this and then to know that the person to be deported twice was operating under three different identifications and then let them, bring them downstairs and out the backdoor and scale the fence to get away, is completely outrageous. And to think a judge would do this completely sort of undermines the confidence people have in our justice system.

MACDONALD: If it is true, they should throw the book at her. Thank you, Sheriff Hodgson, and thank you for your service to our country. Well, we had a jam-packed hour. A lot of news in the show. Thank you so much for having us in your homes and thank you for watching. Lou Dobbs is next right here on Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

END

Bush's Casket Brought To Ellington Field In Houston, Texas And After A Brief Ceremony, The Motorcade Will Proceed To St. Martin's Episcopal Church Where Family And Friends Will Attend A Private Funeral Service Tomorrow; Former President George W. Bush Shared How Their Family Was Grateful That They're Given A Father Like George H.W., One That Every Child Could Wish For, And Also Shared A Funny Side Of His Father Who Hates Vegetables And Especially Broccoli; Dignitaries From Around The World Attended President George H.W. Robert Scales Discusses How Russian President Vladimir Putin Warned That Russia Will Develop Missiles If The U.S. Leaves The Nuclear Arms Treaty; GM CEO Mary Barra Speaks After Meeting With Maryland Delegation; MA Governor Slams Judge For Allegedly Helping Immigrant Avoid ICEElizabeth MacDonald, Edward Lawrence, Andrew Napolitano, Deirdre Bolton

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: You're looking at a live shot. It is a national day of mourning for our 41st President George Herbert Walker Bush. The plane carrying his casket just now arriving at Ellington Field in Houston, Texas.

After a brief ceremony the motorcade will proceed to St. Martin's Episcopal Church where family and friends will attend a private funeral service tomorrow. This, after a moving state funeral held today at Washington National Cathedral.

Hundreds of dignitaries, world leaders, five living presidents gathered. President Bush was celebrated with praise and humor by close friends and his son President George W. Bush broke down crying in an emotional address filled with laughter.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. This is THE EVENING EDIT.

But first, we got breaking news. G.M. CEO Mary Barra running the gauntlet in D.C. Congressmen demanding answers over G.M.'s decision to close plants in the U.S. laying off 14,000 workers.

Edward Lawrence is in Washington with the latest, let's get right to him. Edward, what's going on?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Actually, I want to tell you right now, you are not seeing me because here is the CEO of G.M., Mary Barra, coming in for her next meeting. She's meeting with the delegation from Maryland to talking about why the plant there is going -- is on the list to be slated to close.

Now she is on Capitol Hill today explaining the decision as to why G.M. has to cut 15,000 jobs and close four plants in the United States. Now she met senators from Ohio. She came, just came from a meeting with Ohio congressmen and she needs -- so she needs to restructuring of this of G.M. in order to make the company more viable and have it vibrant for the future.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARY BARRA, CEO, GENERAL MOTORS: Since 2009 we have invested $22 billion in the United States. And in the last couple of years we've invested several more billion dollars and we'll continue to do that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And what's lost in this is there are 3,000 hourly workers who will be able to move within the United States to some other plants there. That still leaves 12,000 people that will be affected by this.

Now Senator Portman says that he asked Mary Barra to put new technology in the plant at least in Ohio to try and bring that plant back to life and save some of those jobs. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ROB PORTMAN, (R) OHIO: She has said to us that she is willing to keep an open mind, but does not want to raise expectations.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now after the meeting here, tomorrow Barra will meet with the Michigan delegation in order to explain exactly what her thinking is with the company going forward. Liz?

MACDONALD: That's real shoe leather journalism, Edward. Great stuff there. Thank you so much for that report, sir. Let's get to Forbes Media chairman, Steve Forbes joins me now. Steve, what's your take on G.M. here?

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Well, I think what you see is poor timing. I think they realize that now announcing this at Thanksgiving and before Christmas. But the fact of the matter is the auto industry is very, very competitive worldwide. People are not buying passenger cars the way they used to, they like the SUVs, they like the trucks. But traditional passenger cars, they don't so much.

And so, I think they probably made the right decision, but the timing of it left something to be desired. But I do think in Lordstown they will do something to keep that plant going even if it's nowhere near the employment they had it before.

MACDONALD: Good point. Steve, let's turn to President George H.W. Bush's funeral today in Washington, D.C. A World War II hero. A man of service and integrity. He helped set the stage for the end of the Cold War era.

Here is the thing, Steve. You say that President Bush's policies also helped set the stage for the economic boom of the 90s, but he's blamed for raising taxes.

FORBES: I thought the decision to raise taxes was the wrong at that time. Still do. But he did other things, such as ending the Cold War, such as dealing with the savings and loan crisis which cost a lot of money, it was a huge strain on U.S. economy. So, he did a lot of things right.

And I think it's beginning to be appreciated today, his role in ending the Cold War without a shot being fired. Because it went so smoothly, we think that was the most of natural thing in the world. No. If he had mishandled that it would have been a disaster. And that was an enormous achievement.

What he did with the Iraq war was an enormous achievement, and so he didn't get credit at the time for those major achievements. But I think people remember him today. And I think, Liz, in the future he's going to be even more influential in death than he was in life by the example he set of service, of civility and putting the country first.

MACDONALD: Yes. You make an important point because the strong American economy equals to -- you know, is helped by a strong American policy, right? In other words, you can't have a strong American economy if you don't have strong foreign policies.

FORBES: Security is essential. That's the first--

MACDONALD: Yes.

FORBES: -- duty of a president or king or whatever. As they used to say, defense of the realm. He was cognizant of that. He did cut back after the end of the Cold War and the military but did so I think in a much more careful manner that was done subsequently.

He was well aware from living through the 30s and 40s, you have to have a good defense. Not too much, but certainly not too little. His leadership in that area I think we could have used in more recent years.

MACDONALD: Steve, you served under President George H.W. Bush as chair of the bipartisan board for international broadcasting. Can you tell us your personal thoughts and memories of the president?

FORBES: Well, he was a president who cared about the country, but he also is very personal. When my father died in early 1990, he called me, expressed condolences, have said nice things about the meetings he had with my father, he said things about what his father meant to him. Those kinds of gestures I think are what truly live.

So, it was a privilege to serve him. He understood the importance of communications and getting America's message out to the world. But he also had that personal touch that really last with you and makes the kind of impression that never leaves you.

MACDONALD: And you could see his son's personal touch too, saying, you know what, he had a horrible short game and he hated vegetables. That was funny. There were funny moments today, right, Steve?

FORBES: There were. It was a wonderful service as everyone has remark. The two and a half hours went very, very quickly. It was a good combination of humor and sadness. And I think what George W. Bush did was the perfect way to end those extraordinary eulogies starting with Meacham, right, Simpsons and the others, of Mulroney, Prime Minister Mulroney. A wonderful, wonderful eulogies to an extraordinary man.

MACDONALD: And Prince Charles representing her majesty the queen who visited with George H.W. Bush and Barbara Bush in 1991. And back then you know, George H.W. Bush was poking fun at the queen. He said, Steve, at the time, you know, you have your, you know, very competitive walking agenda. You had our secret serviceman out of breath trying to keep up with you. The queen.

FORBES: He had that -- he had that personal touch. He could combine seriousness of state with the humorous touches that make for personal relations. And it was personal relations that help in the Cold War in a peaceable way that it did.

Gorbachev learned to trust him. The former head of then declining Soviet Union. He didn't lord it over him. He may practice the diplomacy in a way that this thing could have gone as well as it could. And the idea 10 years before if you'd said that if we're going to win the Cold War without a shot being fired in the peaceful way that it was done, Germany would be reunited as part of NATO and we'd wage a war in the Middle East with the allies from 28 other, 29 other nations, you would have said impossible. But he brought it off.

MACDONALD: All right. Steve Forbes, chair of Forbes Media, great to see you, sir. Thank you so much.

FORBES: Thank you.

MACDONALD: We are joined now by Republican North Dakota Senator John Hoeven. It's great to see you, senator. Thanks for coming in. You attended the funeral today. Can you tell us to what you remember most about today's service?

SEN. JOHN HOEVEN, (R) NORTH DAKOTA: Liz, you know, it was remarkable. The music was incredible. The military, not only the Marine Corps symphony, but also the corps, (Inaudible) corps, the singers, but the presenters were outstanding. But clearly, Bush 43's presentation I think incredibly powerful, particularly when he said about his father. He was the finest father a son could have and he choke up a little bit.

There wasn't a dry eye in the cathedral, there wasn't dry anywhere. It was really powerful.

MACDONALD: Yes, we were covering it on set of Varney, Stuart Varney show and we had tears in our eyes seeing President George W. Bush break down like that and cry. You could see that he was trying to keep it in, right, senator. That he was trying to hold back but when he said and got to the point the last words that his father said in this world were "I love you" to his son, that's when the tears started flowing, right, sir?

HOEVEN: Liz, exactly. You know, President Bush 43 is a strong man and he showed it. You know, you could see he was going through the eulogy and he want to do a good job for his dad. And you know, that final moment, and he was so strong all the way through it.

In that final moment where he said, you know, he was the finest father a son could have, and you know, he choked up at that point. It just that resonated with people. It captured his father. It captured their love. It was really a beautiful moment.

MACDONALD: And dignitaries from around the world were there. We were talking just early about Prince Charles representing her Majesty the Queen.

HOEVEN: Right.

MACDONALD: Also, Angela Merkel, King Hussein of Jordan.

HOEVEN: Right.

MACDONALD: And former British Prime Minister John Major, I mean, he was respected around the world, right, sir?

HOEVEN: Well, that was one of his strengths, right? I mean, his relationships with leaders around the world, and of course, look at his resume before he was president. I mean, he was at the U.N., he was CIA director. He was envoy to China. But that personal touch, I mean, I have a letter from him, you know, which I treasure. And I mean, he reached out to everybody and it was genuine and it was real and he certainly did that on the world stage.

And I think there are leaders across the globe, you know, that still really admire and appreciate George Herbert Walker Bush.

MACDONALD: Senator Hoeven, thank you so much for coming in, sir. We really appreciate it.

HOEVEN: Great to be with you.

MACDONALD: Now what not many may realize is the huge impact President George H.W. Bush had on the Supreme Court, a lasting effect we still feel today.

Let's bring in Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. You point out that he nominated two justices that paved the way for two more.

ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Two very opposite justices. One of whom greatly displeased him and one of them pleased him beyond his wildest imagining. So, David Souter, a patrician Republican like George W. Bush from New England turned out to be the darling of the liberals.

On the side of abortion rights, on the side of expanding congressional regulation of economic rights and famously or infamously on the side of eminent domain whereby the government can seize property, and then sell it to the higher bidder even if it's not going to be put to a public use. The famous Kelo versus New London, Connecticut case. On the other hand, there's Clarence Thomas.

MACDONALD: Right. And is he the longest serving justice on the court right now?

NAPOLITANO: Yes, he is.

MACDONALD: Yes. OK.

NAPOLITANO: He is the senior justice for 27 years. He has shocked even his adversaries, and even his adversaries have praised his work. How do I know this? So, when you teach law school, you use a casebook, about 1500 pages. And it's the cases that first and second year law students need to know.

Flipping through the constitutional criminal procedure casebook and I see opinions by Justice Clarence Thomas. And then I look at the author, the editor of the casebook. Some of the most liberal intelligentsia in the legal community showing respect for the work of Clarence Thomas.

MACDONALD: So, he knew the guys to pick, right? I mean, you also point out--

(CROSSTALK)

NAPOLITANO: I don't know that he could--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: But John Roberts and Samuel Alito he appointed too.

NAPOLITANO: Well, he appointed Mr. John Roberts to the circuit Court of Appeals and he appointed Mr. Samuel Alito to the circuit Court of Appeals. From each of which they ascended to the Supreme Court by his son.

So, I don't know that he could have expected that Justice Thomas would serve as well and as long as he has. here's another little tidbit. This is probably driving Justice Scalia in heaven crazy.

Justice Thomas has more--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Who you knew.

NAPOLITANO: Yes. And I could him about this is he were here. Justice Thomas, Justice Clarence Thomas has more of his own clerks now as federal judges and senior administrators in the nonpolitical appointee in the civil service side of the government than any other justice in the modern era.

Acolytes of his small government, maximum individual liberty dial back the regulators.

MACDONALD: Steve Forbes and John Hoeven. Senator Hoeven is still here. Steve, can you react to just what Judge Napolitano is saying about President George H.W.'s impact on the Supreme Court.

FORBES: Well, I think the judge has summarized it very well and Clarence Thomas being on for as long as he has been, has had that influence. And the fact is that the media just ignores what the impact that he has. And so, you don't read in the public press much about him but he's had the kind of impact that I think George H.W. Bush would've chuckle and appreciated somebody who is a laid-back as the Thomas's as George H.W. Bush was, and but made a huge impact.

Sometimes a less can be so much more. And there are those two are examples of it.

MACDONALD: Senator Hoeven, come in on this. What's your -- you were seeing now the Bush family leaving the plane.

Can you react to what Steve Forbes and Judge Napolitano was just saying, Senator Hoven about the impact in the Supreme Court?

HOEVEN: Absolutely, I totally agree with him. And you know, it's interesting to watch as a family comes off Air Force One. When I've actually flown both President Bush 43 and Present Trump on Air Force One and to see that magnificent aircraft carrying President Bush and the Bush family it's amazing.

You know, but definitely no question that it's been a profound impact on the court.

MACDONALD: You know, you have personal anecdotes, Judge Napolitano. You met George H.W. Bush, right?

NAPOLITANO: Well, the George H.W. Bush that I met was after his presidency. He twice teased me about my height, of course, almost everybody is sure that President George H.W. Bush.

MACDONALD: What did he say?

NAPOLITANO: And listen to this. He was -- so Steve will love and so with the senator. He was twice admonished by Barbara for it.
